DIVISION 5. - ENVIRONMENTAL ADVISORY COMMITTEE 

Sec. 2-271. - Created; function. 
    There is hereby created an environmental advisory committee for the purpose of studying and recommending actions and programs to the city council and city manager to promote educating the public and environmental stewardship by and in the City of Berkley. The environmental advisory committee shall act as a fact finder and advisor to the city council and city manager. 
(Ord. No. O-01-11, § 1, 4-18-2011) 
Sec. 2-272. - Composition; appointment; terms. 
(a)  The environmental advisory committee shall consist of seven members appointed by a majority vote of the city council. Members shall be qualified either by experience or by evidence of interest in protecting the environment or employing environmentally friendly technology and lifestyles. 
(b)  The terms of office of the members of the environmental advisory committee, subject to the provisions of this article relative to removal shall be as follows. Members shall serve a term of three years, except that two members of the first environmental advisory committee to be so appointed shall serve a term of one year, two for a term of two years, and three for a term of three years. The term of office in each instance shall begin on July 1 in each year. 
(Ord. No. O-01-11, § 1, 4-18-2011) 
Sec. 2-273. - Removal from office. 
    Members of the environmental advisory committee shall be subject to removal from office by a majority vote of the council without cause assigned. 
(Ord. No. O-01-11, § 1, 4-18-2011) 
Sec. 2-274. - Filing of vacancies. 
    Vacancies occurring on the environmental advisory committee by other than through the expiration of a term shall be filled for the unexpired term by the council consistent with the provisions of section 2-272. 
(Ord. No. O-01-11, § 1, 4-18-2011) 
Sec. 2-275. - Compensation. 
    Members of the environmental advisory committee shall serve without compensation. 
(Ord. No. O-01-11, § 1, 4-18-2011) 
Sec. 2-276. - Organization; meetings. 
    A chairman, vice-chairman, and secretary shall be selected by environmental advisory committee members. Meetings shall be held at least once every month. Elections of officers shall take place yearly at the July meeting. A quorum shall consist of a majority of members then serving. Minutes shall be properly filed with the city clerk and recommendations and reports promptly presented to the city council and city manager. 
(Ord. No. O-01-11, § 1, 4-18-2011) 
Sec. 2-277. - Funding; personnel. 
    Neither the environmental advisory committee, nor any member thereof, may incur any expense or create any obligation or liability upon the city. If any expenditure of city funds may be required in connection with the functioning of such committee, before such funds shall be expended, approval of such expenditures shall be first obtained by the city manager. The city, as directed by the city manager, may provide assistance as needed. 
(Ord. No. O-01-11, § 1, 4-18-2011) 
Sec. 2-278. - Annual report. 
    The environmental advisory committee shall, on or before July 1 of each year, make a written report to the city council and city manager describing the work of the environmental advisory committee during the preceding year. The environmental advisory committee shall also make such other reports as the council may from time to time require. 
(Ord. No. O-01-11, § 1, 4-18-2011) 
Sec. 2-279. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - CONSULTANT COSTS 

Sec. 2-280. - Purpose. 
    The city council members find that applications for zoning amendments, planned unit developments, special land uses, site plan review, and various other authorizations, permissions, permits, reviews, inspections, selections, services, or approvals, sometimes present special complexities, burdens, or a need for technical expertise such that it is reasonable and appropriate for the city to seek consultation, advice, engineering, legal review, inspection, and assistance from one or more consultants. The city and its boards and commissions should not have to depend solely on information, findings and opinions produced by consultants or persons who work for the applicant or for other parties or agencies. 
    The city further finds that in such circumstances, it appropriate for the applicant, rather than the city and its taxpayers, to bear the cost of engaging such consultants for the city when the need for and benefit of these consulting services is primarily created by and for the applicant. 
    Therefore, it is the city's policy that all such consulting costs incurred by the city should be charged to and paid by the applicant. 
(Ord. No. O-01-18, § 1, 3-5-2018) 
Sec. 2-281. - Review expenses charged to applicant. 
    In circumstances where an applicant requests the city for an authorization, permission, permit, review, inspection, selection, service, or approval for which the city deems it is necessary or appropriate to engage one or more consultants to advise and assist the city, the applicant shall be charged and required to pay the city's cost of the consultant(s). 
(Ord. No. O-01-18, § 1, 3-5-2018) 
Sec. 2-282. - Escrow deposit; documentation of payments from escrow; additional funds; payment in full prior to final approval; refund of surplus. 
    The city may require the applicant to deposit funds in advance to be held by the city in an escrow account in an amount estimated by the city to cover the city's anticipated consultant costs. The city shall draw down from the escrow account to pay its consultant(s). Payments from escrow shall be documented by a written billing or accounting for the consulting work performed and the cost, and such written documentation may be examined by the applicant. If the city later determines its consulting expenses may exceed the amount in escrow, the city may require the applicant to deposit additional amounts. Final approval shall not be issued until the applicant has paid in full the city's consultant costs. Any surplus funds shall be refunded by the city to the applicant or other person who deposited the funds. 
(Ord. No. O-01-18, § 1, 3-5-2018) 
Chapter 6 - ADVERTISING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 30; advertising by massage parlors, § 30-610; signs for garage/estate sales, § 54-36; merchandising, advertising and signs in parks, § 86-67; signs, ch. 94. 
State Law reference- Advertisement Act of 1988, MCL 445.811 et seq., MSA 19.853(41) et seq.; highway advertising, MCL 252.301 et seq., MSA 9.391(101) et seq.; general crimes re: advertising, MCL 750.33 et seq., MSA 28.222 et seq.; deceptive advertising, MCL 445.801 et seq., MSA 19.853(1) et seq.; attaching advertising to trees, MCL 247.235, MSA 9.355. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Billposting. 
    No person shall attach, place, paint, write, stamp or paste any sign, advertisement, or any other matter upon any utility pole, tree, fire hydrant; or on any pavement, sidewalk or crosswalk, public building or any property or thing belonging to the city. Public officers posting any notice required or permitted by law shall be excepted from the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1981, §§ 3-1, 3-2) 
Sec. 6-2. - Violations. 
    Violations of this chapter shall be a municipal civil infraction and prosecuted consistent with the provisions of chapter 82, article IX, pertaining to municipal civil infractions. 
Secs. 6-3-6-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - HANDBILLS 

Sec. 6-31. - Purpose of article. 
    The purpose of this article is to protect the people of the city against careless distribution of handbills and circulars. Such is determined to be detrimental to the public welfare, and it is determined that the public interest, convenience and necessity requires the regulation thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 3-16) 
Sec. 6-32. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Commercial handbills or circulars. Any printed or written matter, any sample or device, dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any printed matter or literature which advertises for sale any merchandise, product, commodity or thing, or which directs attention to any business or mercantile or commercial establishment, or other activity, for the purpose of directly or indirectly promoting the interests thereof by sales. 
(Code 1981, § 3-17) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 6-33. - Exemptions. 
    Exempt from the provisions of this article is the distribution of handbills or circulars primarily or solely pertaining to religious or political activities and any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than 12 issues per year. 
(Code 1981, § 3-18) 
Sec. 6-34. - Licensing. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to circulate, distribute or cause to be circulated or distributed, any commercial handbill or circular, except those pertaining to political or religious activities, unless such person shall have first made application for and obtained a license from the city clerk for the circulation and distribution of commercial handbills or circulars. 
(Code 1981, § 3-19; Ord. No. 28-95, § 1, 3-6-1995) 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits generally, § 30-31 et seq. 
Sec. 6-35. - Display of name of employer. 
    Every agent or employee who shall distribute handbills or circulars in the city shall, while engaged in such distribution, carry a bag or other marking on his person, which shall clearly indicate the name of the company by whom he is employed. 
(Code 1981, § 3-20) 
Sec. 6-36. - Hours. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to distribute handbills or circulars between 9:00 p.m. and 8:00 a.m. 
(Code 1981, § 3-21) 
Sec. 6-37. - Restricted on private premises. 
    No person licensed under the provisions of this article shall distribute, dispose of, place, throw, scatter or cast any handbill or circular in or upon any private property except by attaching such handbill or circular to the door or premises in such manner as to prevent its being blown or drifted about such premises or elsewhere. No such handbill or circular shall be distributed in any manner in or upon any private premises which is temporarily or permanently uninhabited. 
(Code 1981, § 3-22) 
Sec. 6-38. - Prohibited on posted premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person licensed under this article to distribute any handbill or circular upon any premises if requested by anyone thereon not to do so, or if there is placed on the premises a sign bearing the words: "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers or Agents," "No Advertisement" or any similar notice, indicating in any manner that the occupants of the premises do not desire to have handbills or circulars left upon such premises. 
(Code 1981, § 3-23) 
Chapter 10 - ALARM SYSTEMS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 50; law enforcement, ch. 62; false alarms, § 82-38. 

Sec. 10-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known as "The Public Safety Alarm System Ordinance." 
(Code 1981, § 14-161) 
Sec. 10-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Alarm business: Any person engaged in the business of selling, installing, servicing or monitoring an alarm system. 
    Alarm system: An assembly of equipment and devices, or a single device such as a solid state unit, which uses electric energy to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention such as a burglar, robbery, fire or need for medical assistance within a building, structure or facility, or for alerting others to the commission of an unlawful act or hazard within a building, structure or facility and to which police officers, firefighters or public safety officers are expected to respond and which emits a sound or transmits a signal or message when actuated. The term "alarm system" includes, but is not limited to, the terms "audible alarm system," "automatic holdup alarm system," "burglar alarm system" and "manual holdup alarm system" as those terms are defined in this section. Excluded from the definition of the term "alarm system" are systems used solely to alert or signal persons within the premises in which the alarm system is located. 
    Alarm user: Any person owning, leasing, occupying or found in charge of any premises wherein an alarm system is located. 
    Answering service: A telephone answering service providing the service of receiving emergency signals from an alarm system and thereafter relaying the emergency alarm by voice to the public safety department of the city. 
    Audible alarm system: An alarm system which generates an audible sound on the premises when it is actuated which sound can be heard by persons not on the premises. 
    Automatic dialing device: An alarm system which automatically sends over telephone lines, by direct connection or otherwise, a prerecorded voice message or coded signal indicating the existence of the emergency situation an alarm system is intended to detect. 
    Automatic holdup alarm system: An alarm system in which the signal transmission is initiated by the action of the robber. 
    Burglar alarm system: An alarm system signaling an entry or attempted entry into the area protected by the alarm system. 
    False alarm: The activation of an alarm system through mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation or the negligence of the owner or lessee of an alarm system or his employees or agents. In addition, the use of an alarm to summon police, fire or public safety personnel for reasons other than those listed on alarm system permits will also be considered a false alarm. False alarms shall not include alarms caused by electrical interruptions, floods or other natural disasters. 
    Manual holdup alarm system: An alarm system in which the signal transmission is initiated by the direct action of the person attacked or by an observer of the attack. 
    Public safety alarm system: Any one or more of the alarm systems described in this chapter. 
    Subscriber: A person who buys or leases, or otherwise obtains for use upon premises within the city, an alarm system and contracts with or hires an alarm business to monitor or service the alarm system. 
(Code 1981, § 14-162) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 10-3. - Alarm user's installation permit. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person owning, leasing, occupying or being in charge of any real estate in the city to install, cause to be installed or maintain a public safety alarm system without first obtaining a permit to do so issued by the city clerk and paying the fee for such permit fixed by city council resolution. 
(b)  No public safety alarm system permit shall be issued until such system and its installation shall have been approved in writing by the city manager or designee as complying with all applicable building regulations of the city. 
(Code 1981, § 14-163) 
Sec. 10-4. - Automatic dialing devices. 
(a)  No person shall interconnect any automatic dialing device to a public safety department telephone primary trunk line, and no person shall permit any such automatic dialing device to be interconnected to a public safety department telephone primary trunk line. 
(b)  The city manager or designee may, in the exercise of his discretion, approve a direct line installation of an automatic dialing device with all costs of installation and maintenance borne by the alarm system subscriber. 
(Code 1981, § 14-164) 
Sec. 10-5. - Notification. 
(a)  The alarm subscriber shall provide the director of public safety with the names and residence telephone numbers of at least two persons who can be reached by telephone and who can provide entry into the premises wherein an alarm system is located for the purpose of terminating an alarm signal. 
(b)  The alarm subscriber shall provide the name and telephone number of a person employed by an alarm business servicing or monitoring any alarm system who can be reached by telephone at any time, day or night, by the public safety department. 
(c)  No alarm system shall be tested with a resulting transmission of an alarm to the public safety department without first notifying the city manager or designee. 
(Code 1981, § 14-165) 
Sec. 10-6. - False alarm; user fees. 
(a)  There are hereby established by the city fees to be imposed upon and paid by any person required to obtain a permit under this chapter in the event false alarms are transmitted to the public safety department from any alarm system located on premises at which a permit is required to be obtained by such person. 
(b)  Alarm conditions caused by the following circumstances shall not constitute a false alarm for which a user fee is imposed: 
(1)  Alarm system malfunctions, if corrective measures are instituted within 72 hours after the alarm has been transmitted and written proof of repairs is given to the city manager or designee. 
(2)  Alarms activated by storm conditions, motor vehicle and utility pole collisions or disruption of telephone company service. 
(Code 1981, § 14-166) 
Chapter 14 - ALCOHOLIC LIQUORS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 30; sale of alcoholic beverages to intoxicated persons, § 82-153; furnishing of a residence or rental premises to minors in possession of alcohol or drugs, § 82-317; alcoholic liquors and underage persons, § 82-411 et seq.; alcoholic liquor in parks, § 86-65; unlawful blood alcohol content of persons under 21 years of age, § 122-2; cost recovery responses to incidents of driving under the influence of alcohol or drugs, § 122-31 et seq. 
State Law reference- Alcoholic liquor control, MCL 436.1 et seq., MSA 18.971 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 14-1. - Public consumption. 
    It is unlawful for any person to consume alcoholic liquor in a public place except a public place licensed for on-premises consumption of alcoholic liquor. 
Secs. 14-2-14-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LICENSES AND PERMITS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-05-07, § 1, adopted July 16, 2007, amended chapter 14, article II, §§ 14-31-14-37, in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, article II pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from Ord. No. 10-94, §§ 2-8, adopted May 2, 1994. 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits generally, § 30-31 et seq. 
State Law reference- Licenses and local approval thereof, MCL 436.17, MSA 18.988. 

Sec. 14-31. - Purpose-Compliance required. 
    This article is established in order to provide an orderly procedure for the review and consideration by the city of any and all requests for licenses, including requests for new licenses, transfers of existing licenses, placing licenses in escrow, adding or deleting owners and other matters relating to the sale or dispensation of alcoholic beverages within the city. All persons shall strictly comply with the provisions of this article. 
(Ord. No. O-05-07, § 1, 7-16-2007) 
Sec. 14-32. - Definitions. 
    Alcoholic beverage shall mean any intoxicating beverage or sale or dispensation, which is subject to licensure by the laws of the state. 
    Development district license shall refer to those class C liquor licenses available pursuant to Public Act 501 of 2006. At the date of article adoption, the city has five such licenses available to businesses on Twelve Mile Road and five additional such licenses available to businesses on Coolidge. 
    Person shall mean any person or legal entity of whatsoever kind or nature. 
    Quota license shall refer to a class C liquor license, which has yet to be assigned to any person for which the city has authority to issue and assign. "Quota license" shall also mean any licenses which may be issued by the city, pursuant to §§ 531(1), (2), (3), (4) and 521 of the Liquor Control Code of 1998, as amended and any license transfer from outside the city. 
    Transfer license shall refer to an existing class C, class B, private club, SDD or SDM license or other associated permit with any such license which has previously been issued and owned by an existing person and which is subject to a proposed transfer, placement in escrow or the adding or deleting of names or change of ownership, except licenses from outside the city. 
(Ord. No. O-05-07, § 1, 7-16-2007) 
Sec. 14-33. - Requirements and procedure. 
(a)  Application. Any person desiring a quota, development district or transfer of license shall fully complete an application upon a form as prescribed by the city which shall include at minimum the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of applicant; 
(2)  Type of license desired; 
(3)  Address and legal description of subject property; 
(4)  A resume from the applicant and any individual having ownership interest or management responsibilities. The resume shall outline educational background and employment history, including previous liquor licensed establishment experience 
(5)  Any criminal charges or convictions involving the applicant or any person having ownership interest or management responsibilities for the applicant; 
(6)  Any civil actions and/or judgments involving the applicant or any person having ownership interest or management responsibilities for the applicant; 
(7)  Credit history and any history of bankruptcy associated with the applicant and any person having ownership interest or management responsibilities for the applicant; 
(8)  The source of all funding, including verification through furnishing bank records; 
(9)  Detailed plans, including a site plan and interior layout showing bar and seating locations and an architectural elevation. In lieu of such plans, the application must include a narrative detailing future building renovation plans; 
(10)  The date any and all construction or other improvements will commence; 
(11)  The date any and all construction or improvements will be completed and business operations will commence; 
(12)  The cost of all proposed building improvements. State law requires that for a development district license at least $75,000.00 be committed at the time of approval. Prior to issuance of said license, at least $75,000.00 in renovations must be expended. The amount required shall only apply to the development district license. 
(b)  Application submittal. The application and all accompanying documents shall be submitted to the city clerk and the application fee shall be fully paid at the time of submittal. 
(c)  Investigation and release. Upon receipt of a complete application, the city clerk shall distribute copies to the building department and the public safety department for review and recommendation. In addition, any applications involving property within the downtown development authority shall also be forwarded to the downtown development authority for review and recommendation. All recommendations shall be completed within 60 days unless otherwise noted below. 
The public safety department shall conduct an investigation, which shall be completed within 60 days from the date of receipt of the application, unless additional time is required. In the event additional time is required, applicant shall be notified in writing as soon as reasonably practicable with a new proposed date for completion set forth. Additional requests for time may be made in the same manner. The applicant upon request shall execute any and all necessary releases and furnish additional documentation as requested by the public safety department, including, but not limited to, permitting release of employment records, medical records, financial records, arrest and criminal records. Applicant shall promptly execute and submit all releases requested. 
(d)  Recommendation. A recommendation for approval or denial shall be made to the city council. Such recommendation for approval shall refer solely to the question of whether in the opinion of the administration; the applicant appears to have adequate character and fitness. Such recommendation shall not mean that applicant is entitled to the issuances of any license. 
(e)  Approval. The city council, upon recommendation of administration shall consider the application. The city council may grant or deny approval. If approval is granted, the applicant shall be entitled, subject to approval by the state liquor control commission, to the issuance and transfer of a license, provided the representations made in the application and to the city council are fully complied with, including, but not limited to, representations made with regard to the construction, commencement of construction, scope of the project, and any other matters set forth in the application. Any time after approval, the city council may recommend that the license be revoked or not renewed for the following year in the event of any of the following: 
(1)  Any misrepresentations or inaccuracies on the application; 
(2)  Failure to timely commence or complete construction or improvements to the establishment or failure to comply with the plans for the establishment submitted with the application, unless plan changes have been expressly authorized and approved by the city council as part of the application process; 
(3)  Conviction of a crime or the filing of any bankruptcy proceedings. 
(Ord. No. O-05-07, § 1, 7-16-2007) 
Sec. 14-34. - Standards for approval. 
    The following standards shall be considered by the city council: 
(1)  The proposed (or existing) building and site improvements are consistent with the city's master plan objectives and the design of neighboring sites and buildings. 
(2)  The proposed business plan will complement, not unduly harm, existing businesses. 
(3)  The business has been an established city business or the business owner is a resident of the city. 
(4)  The amount of off-street parking is adequate. The city council may require that a cash deposit be furnished by the applicant to be escrowed and later used to create additional parking if needed. 
(5)  The public safety department and building department recommendations. 
(Ord. No. O-05-07, § 1, 7-16-2007) 
Sec. 14-35. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-05-16, § 1, adopted Aug. 15 2016, repealed § 14-35, which pertained to inspections and derived from Ord. No. O-05-07, § 1, 7-16-2007. 
Sec. 14-36. - Outdoor uses in connection with class C liquor-licensed establishments. 
    The purpose of this section is to regulate outdoor uses in connection with class C liquor-licensed establishments in order to provide for the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city, including, but not limited to, the protection of patrons of class C liquor-licensed establishments, the avoidance of blight upon surrounding properties, the preservation of harmonious, aesthetic appearances, and the elimination of conditions interfering with the peaceful enjoyment of surrounding properties. 
    Outdoor dining areas on private property shall be reviewed and approved in accordance with chapter 138, article VI, division 6 of the Code. Approval of consumption of liquor within the outdoor dining area shall only be granted after the dining area has been approved. 
    Sidewalk cafes shall be reviewed and approved in accordance with section 106-42. Approval of consumption of liquor within the sidewalk cafe shall only be granted after the sidewalk cafe has been approved. 
    Temporary sale and consumption of liquor within a tent or other temporary structure shall be reviewed and approved in accordance with chapter 138, article III, division 3 of the Code. Upon receipt of a complete application, administration will forward the matter to the city council for review. 
(Ord. No. O-05-07, § 1, 7-16-2007) 
Sec. 14-37. - Fees. 
    Fees shall be established by resolution of the city council periodically and incorporated into the fee schedule section pursuant to the provisions of such ordinance. All fees are payable upon application in full and are non-refundable. Fees for escrow, transfer, or addition or deletion of persons or entities to a license, change of names shall be the same amount as provided for transfer. Relocation of an existing license to a new site shall be pursuant to the fee set forth herein. The following initial fees are established: 
Quota licenses ..... $300.00 
Transfer licenses ..... 200.00 
Development district licenses ..... 300.00 
Amendments to existing licenses ..... 100.00 
Annual inspection ..... 100.00 
(Ord. No. O-05-07, § 1, 7-16-2007) 
Sec. 14-38. - Penalty. 
    Violation of this article shall be a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. O-05-07, § 1, 7-16-2007) 
Chapter 18 - AMUSEMENTS AND ENTERTAINMENTS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 30. 
State Law reference- Public exhibitions and entertainments, MCL 750.463 et seq., MSA 28.718 et seq.; Carnival-Amusement Safety Act of 1966, MCL 408.651 et seq., MSA 18.484(1) et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 18-1-18-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - AMUSEMENT DEVICES[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Coin-operated devices, unlawful to break into, MCL 752.811, 752.812, MSA 28.643(101), 28.643(102); pinball machines permitted on premises where alcoholic beverages are sold, MCL 436.28a, MSA 18.999(1). 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Coin-operated amusement device means any amusement machine or device, whether video, electronic or mechanical, operated by means of the insertion of a coin, token or similar object, or upon payment of a price for a measured term of play or operation, for use for the purpose of entertainment, amusement or game of skill. The term does not include a vending machine which delivers a product such as candy, food, cigarettes, newspapers or personal items as its function; nor does the term include devices which provide music as their function. 
    Coin-operated amusement ride means any device or assembly operated by motor power designed to be occupied or operated by one or more persons for the purpose of amusement or entertainment, to be operated by means of the insertion of a coin, token or similar object, or upon the payment of a price for a measured term of ride or operation. 
    Commercial amusement device center means any place, premises, room, building or establishment in which three or more coin-operated amusement devices, coin-operated amusement rides, or combination thereof, are located. 
(Code 1981, § 4-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-32. - Applicability of article provisions. 
(a)  The provisions of this article do not apply to any establishment which has been issued a license for on-premises sale of alcoholic liquor. 
(b)  The provisions of this article do not apply to any establishment or community organization which has been issued a permit by the city for such event. 
Sec. 18-33. - Location of commercial amusement device center. 
    No commercial amusement device center shall be located or established within 100 feet of any residence or within 500 feet of any church or school building. No commercial amusement device center license shall be issued to a location within 1,000 feet of an existing commercial amusement device center. The distances between such commercial amusement device centers and any residence, church or school building or any existing commercial amusement device center shall be measured along a straight line between the two closest points from the part of the residence, church or school building or existing commercial amusement device center nearest to the contemplated location and from the part of the contemplated location nearest to the residence, church or school building or existing commercial amusement device center. 
(Code 1981, § 4-20) 
Sec. 18-34. - Prohibited at drive-in restaurants. 
    No coin-operated device or coin-operated ride shall be maintained, used, operated or permitted in a drive-in restaurant as defined and licensed under the provisions of chapter 30, article VIII. 
(Code 1981, § 4-22) 
Cross reference- Drive-in restaurants generally, § 30-376 et seq. 
Sec. 18-35. - Hours of operation. 
    No commercial amusement device center shall be open between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 9:00 a.m. 
(Code 1981, § 4-23) 
Sec. 18-36. - Attendance by juveniles. 
(a)  No minor child under the age of 16 years shall be permitted in a commercial amusement device center or shall be permitted to operate any coin-operated amusement device before the hour of 3:00 p.m. on days during which school is in session. 
(b)  No minor child under the age of 17 years shall be permitted to remain in a commercial amusement device center between the hours of 10:30 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. unless accompanied by their parent or guardian. 
(c)  It shall be the responsibility of the owner or person in charge of any commercial amusement device center to prohibit or exclude minor children from the premises under the provisions of subsections (a) and (b) of this section. 
(Code 1981, § 4-24) 
Cross reference- Offenses involving underage persons, § 82-316 et seq. 
Sec. 18-37. - Gambling. 
(a)  No owner or person in control of the premises where any coin-operated amusement device is located, shall permit the use of any such device for the purpose of gambling. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to give any prize, award, merchandise, gift or anything of value, other than free games, to any player, or to any operator of any coin-operated amusement device for a high score thereon or other accomplishment of skill or chance. 
(Code 1981, § 4-25) 
Secs. 18-38-18-60. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits generally, § 30-31 et seq. 

Sec. 18-61. - Required. 
    No person, as owner or proprietor, shall establish, maintain, operate, control or engage in the business of operating a commercial amusement device center, coin-operated amusement device or coin-operated amusement ride without first obtaining the proper license required under this article. 
(Code 1981, § 4-17; Ord. No. 29-95, § 1, 3-6-1995) 
Sec. 18-62. - Application and fees. 
(a)  Applications shall be made for the licensing of coin-operated amusement devices, coin-operated amusement rides and commercial amusement device centers to the city clerk upon an application form to be prescribed by the city clerk and shall include the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner of each such device or ride if the applicant is not the true owner of such device or ride. 
(2)  A brief description of each such device or ride. 
(3)  The name and address of the applicant, including the names and addresses of all members of any firm, partnership, association or corporation to be licensed under this article. 
(b)  The license fees for coin-operated amusement devices, coin-operated amusement rides and commercial amusement device centers shall be as hereafter prescribed by resolution of city council. 
(c)  Each such license shall expire on December 31 next following its issuance, and successive renewals of any such license shall require a new application and payment of the current license fees. 
(d)  Each such license issued for an amusement device or amusement ride shall be freely transferable without an additional fee to replace or substitute devices or rides and shall be displayed in the establishment wherein such devices or rides are located so as to be clearly visible to the public. 
(e)  All such commercial amusement device center uses shall be approved by the city council before issuance. 
(Code 1981, § 4-18) 
Sec. 18-63. - Compliance with zoning and building codes. 
    No license under this article shall be issued until the building inspector has certified that the location at which such license will be established complies in every respect with this Code of Ordinances including, but not limited to, chapter 138, the zoning ordinance; chapter 26, the general building regulations; and all BOCA building, plumbing, electrical and fire codes adopted by the city. 
(Code 1981, § 4-19) 
Cross reference- Building code, § 26-31 et seq.; zoning, ch. 138. 
Sec. 18-64. - Area required for each device or ride. 
(a)  Only one such license shall be issued for such device or ride for each 60 square feet of net floor area. For the purpose of determining the number of such licenses permitted at a location, the net floor area shall be that area actually occupied and devoted to the placement of such coin-operated amusement devices or rides and shall not include accessory unoccupied rooms, restroom areas, storage areas or mechanical equipment rooms, and thickness of walls, and no such device or ride shall be placed within a distance of three feet from another device or ride. 
(b)  A scale diagram of the premise which depicts the location of each ride or device to be located on such premises, and each exit from the premises shall be submitted to the building inspector and public safety director at the time of license application to assist in determining compliance with all city codes and ordinances. 
(Code 1981, § 4-21) 
Sec. 18-65. - Revocation. 
    Any license granted pursuant to this article shall be subject to the provisions of chapter 30, article II of this Code. 
(Code 1981, § 4-26) 
Secs. 18-66-18-95. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - POOL, BILLIARDS AND BOWLING 

Sec. 18-96. - Licensing. 
    No person shall establish, maintain or operate within the city any billiard parlors, pool rooms or bowling alleys, without first obtaining a license therefor. 
(Code 1981, § 4-34) 
Cross reference- Businesses licenses and permits generally, § 30-31 et seq. 
Sec. 18-97. - Gambling. 
    No owner or person in control of the premises wherein any billiard tables, pool tables or bowling alleys are located shall knowingly permit the use or occupancy thereof for gambling or the allowance of free games. 
(Code 1981, § 4-35) 
Chapter 22 - ANIMALS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Dogs in parks, § 86-60. 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt animal control ordinance, MCL 287.290. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 22-1. - Qualification of animal control officers. 
    Persons who enforce this chapter shall have the qualifications provided in section 29b of the Dog Law of 1919 (MCL 287.289b). 
(Ord. No. O-02-17, § 1, 6-5-2017) 
Cross reference- Officers and employees generally, § 2-36 et seq. 
State Law reference- Minimum qualifications of animal control officers, MCL 287.289c. 
Sec. 22-2. - Cruelty. 
    No person shall cruelly treat or abuse any animal or bird. 
(Code 1981, § 5-1) 
Sec. 22-3. - Poisoning. 
    No person shall throw or deposit any poisonous substance on any exposed public or private place where it endangers, or is likely to endanger, any animal or bird. 
(Code 1981, § 5-2) 
State Law reference- Poisoning of animals, MCL 750.437. 
Sec. 22-4. - Birds and birds' nests. 
    No person, except a public officer acting in his official capacity, shall molest, injure, kill or capture any wild bird, or molest or disturb any wild bird's nest or the contents thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 5-3) 
Sec. 22-5. - Keeping of domestic animals and fowl. 
    No person shall harbor or house any animals or domestic fowl within the city except dogs, cats, birds, fowl or animals commonly classified as pets, or chickens in accordance with article IV of this chapter. 
(Code 1981, § 5-4; Ord. No. O-02-17, § 1, 6-5-2017) 
Sec. 22-6. - Animals deemed public nuisances. 
    Any animal which shall, by loud or frequent or habitual barking, yelping or howling, or other noises, cause serious annoyance to the neighborhood, or which shall injure or destroy real or personal property of persons other than its owner, or molest or injure any person, or shall cause unsanitary conditions because of droppings, uneaten food, or any other thing to cause odor or attraction of flies and vermin, shall be deemed a public nuisance per se, and the owner deemed in violation of the provisions of this section. 
(Code 1981, § 5-5; Ord. No. 61-95, § 1, 5-1-1995) 
Cross reference- Nuisances generally, ch. 78. 
Sec. 22-7. - Violations. 
    Violations of this chapter are misdemeanors except for the following sections and articles which are municipal civil infractions: sections 22-42, 22-44, 22-71 and 22-74, and article IV. 
(Ord. No. O-02-17, § 1, 6-5-2017) 
Secs. 22-8-22-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOGS AND CATS[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Dogs, MCL 287.261 et seq. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 22-41. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Owner (when applied to the proprietorship of a dog or cat): Every person having a right of property in such dog or cat, and every person who keeps or harbors such dog or cat or has it in his care, and every person who permits such dog or cat to remain in or about any premises occupied by him. 
    Reasonable control: Keeping a dog on suitable leash and keeping a cat under the oral control of the owner or custodian or some other person with the permission of the owner or custodian in all cases other than private property unless the dog or cat is confined in a closed automobile or shipping receptacle. 
(Code 1981, § 5-17) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 22-42. - Limitation on number kept. 
(a)  For the purposes of this section, the words "dwelling unit" shall mean a building, or portion thereof, designed for occupancy by one family for residential purposes and having cooking facilities. 
(b)  There shall not be kept or harbored in a dwelling unit more than a total of three dogs or three cats or three of a combination thereof of the age of six months or over. 
(Code 1981, § 5-18) 
Sec. 22-43. - Harborage of canine hybrids. 
(a)  The harborage of any canine hybrid is hereby prohibited. A canine hybrid is defined as any animal which is conceived as the result of the mating of a domestic dog to either a wolf, coyote, dingo, canine hybrid or other nondomestic canid. 
(b)  Harborage shall consist of ownership, providing housing, food or shelter, or protecting and treating an animal as though it lives at a house or commercial location, other than a veterinary hospital or shelter. 
(c)  If there is a probable cause to believe that such an animal is being harbored within the city, the public safety officer is authorized to make a reasonable inquiry into the heritage of such animal and issue a complaint thereon. 
(Ord. No. O-12-97, § 2, 3-17-1997) 
Sec. 22-44. - Maintaining under reasonable control. 
(a)  The owner of any dog or cat shall keep such dog or cat under reasonable control. 
(b)  Every female dog or cat in heat shall be kept confined in a building or secure enclosure by the owner, in such a manner that she will not be in contact, except for intentional breeding purposes, with another dog or cat, nor create a nuisance by attracting other animals. 
(c)  The owner of every dog or cat who permits dog or cat droppings to occur on any public street, right-of-way, park or public place or to occur on the property of others shall be deemed in violation of this section. 
(Code 1981, § 5-19) 
Sec. 22-45. - Rabies prevention and control. 
    No person shall own or harbor a vicious dog or cat or a dog or cat that has been bitten by any animal known to be afflicted with rabies. Any person who shall have in his possession a dog or cat which has contracted, or is suspected of having contracted, rabies, or which has been bitten by any animal known to have been afflicted with rabies, shall, upon demand of the health officer, or any public safety officer or designated authority of the city, produce and surrender such dog or cat to the health department or public safety department of the city to be held for observation or treatment. With the approval of the health department, any such dog or cat may instead be surrendered to a registered veterinarian, or to any approved nonprofit corporation organized for the purpose of sheltering dogs and cats. It shall be the duty of any person owning or harboring a dog or cat which has been attacked or bitten by another dog, cat or other animal showing the symptoms of rabies to immediately notify the public safety department that such person has such dog or cat in his possession. Whenever a dog or cat is brought to the pound for having bitten a person, the animal warden or other duly authorized officer may, if deemed necessary and advisable, and after holding such dog or cat a sufficient length of time to meet the requirements of the health department for investigation, cause such dog or cat to be destroyed as a vicious dog or cat. 
(Code 1981, § 5-20) 
Sec. 22-46. - Housing for stray and unwanted animals. 
    The city shall provide a pound strategically located and it shall be the duty of the dog warden or any other person employed by the city manager for that purpose to properly seize, take up and place in such pound dogs and cats running at large or being kept or harbored in any place of the city contrary to the provisions of this article. 
(Code 1981, § 5-21) 
Sec. 22-47. - Kennels prohibited in residential area. 
    No license of dog or cat kennels or catteries shall be issued and the maintenance of any kennel or cattery or the owning, possessing or harboring of dogs or cats for breeding or commercial purpose in any residential neighborhood is hereby declared to be a nuisance per se which may be abated in any court of competent jurisdiction. 
(Code 1981, § 5-22) 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 30; zoning, ch. 138. 
Sec. 22-48. - Damages incurred by. 
    Every owner of a dog or cat shall be liable for damages for any and all injuries to person or property that may be caused by such dog or cat on any public highway or other public place to be determined and collected in appropriate legal proceedings, in which proceedings any failure or refusal by such owner to comply with the requirements of this article shall constitute prima facie evidence of negligence. 
(Code 1981, § 5-23) 
Sec. 22-49. - Duties of the animal warden. 
(a)  The animal warden shall promptly seize, take up and place in the pound all dogs and cats found running at large or being kept or harbored any place within the city contrary to the provisions of this article or, in lieu of impoundment, the animal warden, public safety officer or other designated authority, is hereby authorized the power to issue Code violation tickets to known owners of such animals who are in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(b)  The animal warden may sell or otherwise dispose of a dog or cat from and after four days of its acquisition. If the dog or cat has a collar, license or other evidence of ownership, the animal warden shall notify the owner in writing and disposition of the animal shall not be made within seven days from the date of certified mailing of the notice. In addition, the animal warden shall maintain a record on each identifiable dog or cat acquired, indicating a basic description of the animal, the date it was acquired and under what circumstances. The record shall also indicate the date of notice sent to the owner of an animal and subsequent disposition. 
(c)  Subsection (b) of this section does not apply to animals which are sick or injured to the extent that the holding period would cause undue suffering, or to animals whose owners request immediate disposal. 
(Code 1981, § 5-24) 
Sec. 22-50. - Release from the pound. 
    No dog or cat shall be released from the pound unless the owner or person entitled to claim the animal shall pay the fees and charges as set forth by resolution of the city council, which resolution may thereafter be modified or revised from time to time. 
(1)  Impounding fees; 
(2)  The cost of board, rabies vaccination and other care and treatment, if necessary; and 
(3)  Any license fees required. 
(Code 1981, § 5-25) 
Secs. 22-51-22-70. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 22-71. - Required. 
    It shall be the duty of any person owning or harboring any dog or cat within 30 days after it becomes four months of age, or within 30 days after such person becomes a resident of the city, or within 30 days after such person becomes the owner of a dog or cat four months of age or more, whichever is later, to apply for a license as provided in this division. 
(Code 1981, § 5-33; Ord. No. 26-95, § 1, 2-6-1995; Ord. No. 33-95, § 1, 3-6-1995; Ord. No. O-15-97, § 2, 4-7-1997; Ord. No. O-7-99, § 1, 9-20-1999) 
Sec. 22-72. - Application. 
(a)  The applicant for a dog or cat license shall give his full name and address and the age and description of the dog or cat. If the applicant has become a resident of the city within 30 days or the owner of a dog or cat within 30 days, the applicant shall give the date of becoming a resident or acquiring the dog or cat, as the case may be. 
(b)  The application for a dog or cat license shall be accompanied by proof of vaccination for rabies, with a vaccine licensed by the United States Department of Health. 
(Code 1981, § 5-34; Ord. No. O-15-97, § 4, 4-7-1997) 
Sec. 22-73. - Issuance. 
    Individual dog licenses to own or harbor a dog and individual cat licenses to own or harbor a cat shall be issued by the city clerk, or a representative of the city clerk, upon application and payment of a license fee as presently established or as hereafter prescribed by resolution of the council. 
(Code 1981, § 5-35) 
Sec. 22-74. - Tags. 
(a)  Upon the issuance of an individual dog license and upon the issuance of an individual cat license, the city clerk shall deliver to the applicant a metal tag of not less than one inch in length or diameter, and bearing a serial number, together with the words "Berkley, Michigan" and such serial number shall be inscribed upon the license so issued. Such metal tag shall be attached to the dog or cat for which it is issued by means of a substantial collar or harness, and no person shall remove any license tag from any dog or cat without the consent of the owner or of the person to whom the license is issued. No tag shall be used on the collar or harness of any other dog or cat than that for which the tag was issued. 
(b)  If the metal license tag is lost, the city clerk may issue a duplicate if the owner of the dog or cat for whom the tag was issued presents the certificate showing the dog or cat was immunized against rabies and a certificate of the dog or cat license, and pays the cost of furnishing a replacement tag. 
(Code 1981, § 5-36; Ord. No. 34-95, § 1, 3-6-1995; Ord. No. O-15-97, § 6, 4-7-1997) 
Sec. 22-75. - Expiration; renewal fee. 
    Licenses may be issued for a one-, two-, or three-year period. No license will be issued beyond the expiration date on the rabies certificate. Licenses not renewed within 30 days of the expiration date of the license shall be subject to a late fee as set forth in the city's fee schedule. 
(Code 1981, § 5-37; Ord. No. 26-95, § 4, 2-6-1995; Ord. No. O-15-97, § 8, 4-7-1997) 
Secs. 22-76-22-84. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COMMERCIAL KENNELS 

Sec. 22-85. - Required. 
    Commercial kennels may be permitted in certain districts specified in the zoning ordinance, subject to the following: 
(1)  No person, other than a licensed veterinarian, shall operate a kennel in the city except in the area zoned the 11 mile district. 
(2)  The facility shall be licensed by the Oakland County Department of Animal Control. 
(3)  A current copy of the county license must be prominently displayed on the kennel premises at all times and a current copy must be filed with the city clerk. 
(4)  Each animal shall have sufficient space to stand up, lie down and turn around without touching the sides or top of cages. 
(5)  All animals shall have fresh water available at all times. 
(6)  All pens and outdoor exercise runs shall be enclosed with a minimum height of eight feet on all sides. 
(7)  All exercise runs shall be made of concrete or a similar impervious material. 
(8)  All exercise runs shall be cleaned and disinfected on a daily basis. 
(9)  Dogs shall only be permitted outside between the hours of 6:30 a.m. and 10:30 p.m. 
(10)  All animals shall be adequately housed, fenced and maintained so as not to become a public or private nuisance. The premises shall be maintained in such a manner so as not to be harmful to surrounding properties, disturb the peace or create any hazard or detriment to public health. 
(Ord. No. O-02-09, § 2, 4-6-2009) 
ARTICLE IV. - CHICKENS 

Sec. 22-90. - Generally. 
(a)  Any person residing in a single-family detached dwelling on residential zoned district property (R-1A, R-1B, R-1C, or R-1D), after obtaining an annual permit from the city, may keep on the property not more than three hen (female) chickens for personal use only and not for any business or commercial use. 
(b)  Chickens may be kept as family pets or to lay eggs for personal consumption only. 
(c)  Slaughtering of any chickens on the property is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. O-02-17, § 2, 6-5-2017) 
Sec. 22-91. - Licensing and inspections. 
(a)  Completed permit applications shall be submitted to the building and code enforcement department along with the fee which shall be established by city council resolution. Approved permit holders shall schedule an inspection within 30 days of permit issuance. Failure to schedule an inspection shall result in an automatic suspension of the permit. If an inspection identifies noncompliance with any of the requirements set forth in this article, the permit holder shall have 14 days after being served with written notice of noncompliance to achieve compliance with the requirements, or the building official may revoke the permit or cite the violation as a municipal civil infraction. 
(b)  Permits shall be valid for up to one year, shall be non-transferable, site-specific and shall expire on March 31 of the next calendar year. A person who wants to continue keeping chickens must obtain a new permit prior to expiration of the previous permit. 
(c)  After an initial inspection, permitted coops shall be inspected at least one additional time during the permit term. 
(Ord. No. O-02-17, § 2, 6-5-2017) 
Sec. 22-92. - Number limit. 
    A person who keeps chickens shall comply with the following requirements: 
(1)  Keep no more than three hen chickens at any time; and 
(2)  Roosters or male chickens or any other type or class of fowl or poultry are prohibited. 
(Ord. No. O-02-17, § 2, 6-5-2017) 
Sec. 22-93. - Enclosure. 
(a)  Chickens shall be contained and kept in a fully enclosed structure, known as a "coop," or a fenced enclosure, known as a "pen," at all times. Fenced enclosures may be wire mesh with openings no larger than 1/4 inch. A chicken coop shall be constructed of durable materials and shall be properly maintained in accordance with the Property Maintenance Code adopted in section 26-276 of the City Code, as amended. 
(b)  A chicken "coop" will be considered to be an accessory structure and must meet all requirements of chapter 138, article III, division 1, of the Zoning Code, except that the structure need not have a concrete foundation slab and a chicken coop may be located within ten feet of an existing accessory structure. Prior to construction, an approved accessory structure permit must be obtained from the building and code enforcement department. 
(c)  A coop or pen shall be designed to provide safe and humane living conditions for the chickens while minimizing adverse impacts (including, but not limited to, odor, noise, insects and dust) on neighbors, and shall meet all of the following additional requirements: 
(1)  A coop or pen shall be detached from the residential dwelling and shall not be located closer than 30 feet to the nearest point of any residential dwelling on an adjacent parcel; 
(2)  A coop or pen shall not be located within any required side or rear yard setback area; 
(3)  A coop or pen shall not exceed six feet in height and 80 square feet in floor area; 
(4)  The use of corrugated metal/fiberglass, sheet metal, plastic tarps, scrap lumber or similar materials is prohibited; and 
(5)  A coop or pen must be completely enclosed with a top or cover. 
(d)  A coop or pen shall be constructed and maintained with a rat wall or similar block foundation or may be raised a minimum height of one foot off the ground to prevent rats, mice, and other rodents or burrowing animals from harboring beneath or entering the coop or pen. Noncompliance with this requirement shall be considered to be a nuisance subject to chapter 78 of the City Code. 
(e)  All feed and other items associated with the keeping of chickens likely to attract rats, mice, or other rodents or vermin shall be secured and protected in sealed, rodent-proof containers. 
(Ord. No. O-02-17, § 2, 6-5-2017; Ord. No. O-09-18, § 1, 8-13-2018) 
Sec. 22-94. - Care of chickens. 
(a)  Chickens shall be kept in compliance with the current Michigan Department of Agriculture Generally Accepted Agricultural and Management Practices for the Care of Farm Animals, as it relates to laying chickens, except as otherwise provided in this section. 
(b)  Chickens shall not be kept in any location on the property other than the rear yard. For purposes of this section, "rear yard" means that portion of a lot enclosed by the property's rear lot line and the side lot lines to the points where the side lot lines intersect with an imaginary line established by the rear of the single-family structure and extending to the side lot lines. 
(Ord. No. O-02-17, § 2, 6-5-2017) 
Sec. 22-95. - Private restrictions. 
    The provisions of this article are independent of, and are not intended to supersede or affect any private restriction, covenant or bylaw that may apply to the property. 
(Ord. No. O-02-17, § 2, 6-5-2017) 
Sec. 22-96. - Violations. 
    A violation of any provision of this article shall be deemed a municipal civil infraction subject to the procedures, sanctions, and remedies prescribed in article IX of chapter 82 of the City Code. 
(Ord. No. O-02-17, § 2, 6-5-2017) 
Sec. 22-97. - Limitation on permits. 
    The city will limit the number of annual permits issued and outstanding to a maximum of five, and permits will be available on a first-come-first-served basis. 
(Ord. No. O-02-17, § 2, 6-5-2017; Ord. No. O-09-18, § 1, 8-13-2018) 
Chapter 26 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 26-1. - Failure to correct violations. 
    The City of Berkley may refuse to issue new permits to a licensed contractor who has failed to correct violations or to any licensed contractor representing a firm which has failed to correct violations. Violations shall include outstanding invoices to the city. 
(Ord. No. O-03-11, § 1, 10-17-2011) 
Secs. 26-2-26-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-4-02, § 1, adopted May 6, 2002, amended art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, art. II, consisting of §§ 26-31-26-35, pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1981, §§ 6-16-6-20, Ord. No. 12-94, § 1, adopted June 20, 1994, and Ord. No. O-3-97, § 1, adopted February 17, 1997.

Sec. 26-31. - Adoption of Michigan Building Code. 
    Pursuant to the provisions of the Michigan Building Code, in accordance with Section 8b(6) of Act 230, of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended, the building official of the city is hereby designated as the enforcing agency to discharge the responsibility of the city under Act 230, of the Public Acts of 1972, as amended, State of Michigan. The city assumes responsibility for the administration and enforcement of said Act throughout its corporate limits. 
(Ord. No. O-4-02, § 1, 5-6-2002) 
Sec. 26-32. - Code on file. 
    Complete printed copies of the Michigan Building Code, including those standards referred to in the building code text, appendices and supplements, adopted in section 26-31, are available for public use and inspection at the building department. 
(Ord. No. O-4-02, § 1, 5-6-2002) 
Secs. 26-33-26-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - BUILDING CODE BOARD OF APPEALS[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-176 et seq. 

Sec. 26-66. - Means of appeal. 
    Any person affected by a decision of the code official or a notice or order issued under this building code shall have the right to appeal to the building code board of appeals, provided that a written application for appeal is filed within 20 days after the day the decision, notice or order was served. An application for appeal shall be based on a claim that the true intent of this code or the rules legally adopted thereunder have been incorrectly interpreted, the provisions of this code do not fully apply, or the requirements of this code are adequately satisfied by other means. 
(Ord. No. 18-94, § 1, 7-18-1994) 
Sec. 26-67. - Power to interpret code. 
    The building code board of appeals shall have the power to interpret the provisions of this code upon application in writing by the owner or lessee or their duly authorized agent, when there are practical difficulties in the way of carrying out the strict letter of the code, so that the spirit of the code shall be observed, public health, safety and welfare secured and substantial justice done. The particulars of such interpretation when granted or allowed and any decision of the building code board of appeals shall be entered upon the records and a signed copy be furnished to the applicant. 
(Ord. No. 18-94, § 1, 7-18-1994) 
Sec. 26-68. - Membership; terms; qualifications. 
(a)  The building code board of appeals shall consist of five members appointed by the mayor, with advice and consent of council, as follows: one for five years, one for four years, one for three years, one for two years and one for one year. Thereafter, each new member shall serve for five years or until a successor has been appointed. 
(b)  The building code board of appeals shall consist of five individuals, one from each of the following professions or disciplines: 
(1)  A registered design professional who is a registered architect; or a builder or superintendent of building construction with at least ten years experience, five of which shall have been in responsible charge of work. 
(2)  A registered design professional with structural engineering or architectural experience. 
(3)  A registered design professional with mechanical or plumbing engineering experience; or a mechanical or plumbing contractor with at least ten years experience, five of which shall have been in responsible charge of work. 
(4)  A registered design professional with electrical engineering experience; or an electrical contractor with at least ten years experience, five of which shall have been in responsible charge of work. 
(5)  A registered design professional with fire protection engineering experience; or a fire protection contractor with at least ten years experience, five of which shall have been in responsible charge of work. 
(Ord. No. 18-94, § 1, 7-18-1994) 
Sec. 26-69. - Alternates; officers; disqualifications; compensation. 
(a)  The mayor, with the advice and consent of the council, shall appoint two alternate members who shall be called by the building code board of appeals chairman to hear appeals during the absence or disqualification of a member. Alternate members shall possess the same qualifications required for building code board of appeals membership, by any one of the above and shall be appointed for five years or until a successor has been appointed. 
(b)  The building code board of appeals shall annually select one of its members to serve as chairman. 
(c)  A member shall not hear an appeal in which that member has any personal, professional or financial interest. 
(d)  A qualified person shall be designated to serve as secretary to the building code board of appeals. The secretary shall file a detailed record of all proceedings in the office of the city manager. 
(e)  Compensation of members shall be determined by a resolution of the council in conformity with state law. 
(Ord. No. 18-94, § 1, 7-18-1994) 
Sec. 26-70. - Meetings and hearings. 
(a)  Notice of meeting. The building code board of appeals shall meet upon notice from the chairman, within ten days of the filing of an appeal, or at stated periodic meetings. 
(b)  Open hearing. All hearings before the building code board of appeals shall be open to the public. The appellant, the appellant's representative, the code official, and any person whose interests are affected shall be given an opportunity to be heard. 
(1)  Procedure. The building code board of appeals shall adopt and make available to the public through the secretary, procedures under which a hearing will be conducted. The procedures shall not require compliance with strict rules of evidence but shall mandate that only relevant information be received. 
(2)  Postponed hearing. When five members are not present to hear an appeal, either the appellant or the appellant's representative shall have the right to request a postponement of the hearing. 
(3)  Board decision. The building code board of appeals shall modify or reverse the decision of the code official by a concurring vote of three members. 
(4)  Resolution. The decision of the building code board of appeals shall be by resolution. Certified copies shall be furnished to the appellant and to the code official. 
(5)  Administration. The code official shall take immediate action in accordance with the decision of the building code board of appeals. 
(c)  Court review. Any person, whether or not a previous party of the appeal, shall have the right to apply to the appropriate court for a writ of certiorari to correct errors of law. Application for review shall be made in the manner and time required by law following the filing of the decision in the office of the chief administrative officer. 
(Ord. No. 18-94, § 1, 7-18-1994) 
Secs. 26-71-26-100. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ELECTRICAL CODE[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-05-04, § 1, adopted December 20, 2004, amended article IV in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, article IV pertained to similar subject matter and derived from the Code of 1981, §§ 6-32, 6-33, 6-39; Ord. No. 13-94, § 1, adopted June 20, 1994; Ord. No. O-4-97, § 1, adopted February 17, 1997; Ord. No. O-19-97, § 1, adopted August 18, 1997; Ord. No. O-2-00, § 1, adopted March 6, 2000; Ord. No. O-03-01, § 1, adopted April 16, 2001. 
Cross reference- Utilities, ch. 126. 
State Law reference- State Construction Code Act of 1972, MCL 125.1501 et seq. 

Sec. 26-101. - Adoption of National Electrical Code and Part I of the Michigan Bureau of Construction Codes. 
    The National Electrical Code, 2002 edition, as promulgated and published by the National Fire Prevention Association, Quincy, Massachusetts, as NFPA Standard No. 70-1999, Part 8 of the Michigan Bureau of Construction Codes as amended are hereby adopted by reference by the city, as in this article modified, for the purpose of regulating the installation, alteration, repair, conversion, use and maintenance of all new electric wiring for light, heat, power and electrical service equipment including sign wiring, fire alarm, communication and television systems, and alterations or extension to existing wiring systems in buildings and structures. 
(Ord. No. O-5-04, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 26-102. - Low voltage wiring. 
    Low voltage wiring in buildings containing multiple family residential, commercial, office, or industrial uses shall require a permit. Low voltage wiring, including but not limited to, telephone lines, cable lines, burglar and fire alarms, that is less than 50 volts AC or DC shall comply with Articles 700 and 800 of the National Electric Code 2002. 
(Ord. No. O-5-04, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 26-103. - Code on file. 
    Complete printed copies of the 2002 National Electrical Code, as promulgated and published by the National Fire Prevention Association, Quincy, Massachusetts, as NFPA Standard No. 70-1999, Part 8 of the Michigan Bureau of Construction Codes as amended, adopted in section 26-101, are available for public use and inspection at the offices of the city clerk and the building department. 
(Ord. No. O-5-04, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 26-104. - Building code board of appeals. 
    The building code board of appeals of the city is hereby constituted as the electrical code board of appeals under this article. 
(Ord. No. O-5-04, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 26-105. - Fees for electrical permits. 
    When an application is made for a permit to equip any building with electric fixtures or wiring for heat, light or power, a fee shall be paid in an amount as presently established or as hereafter prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(Ord. No. O-5-04, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Sec. 26-106. - Liability. 
    This article shall not be construed to relieve from or lessen the responsibility or liability of any party owning, operating, controlling or installing any electrical wiring, electric device or electric material for damages to persons or property caused by any defect therein nor shall the city be held as assuming any such liability by reason of the inspection authorized in this article, or certificate of inspection issued as provided in this article. 
(Ord. No. O-5-04, § 1, 12-20-2004) 
Secs. 26-107-26-135. - Reserved.
