It shall likewise be unlawful for any person to wear, carry or display any emblem, insignia or other means of identification as a member of the emergency management division of the city, unless authority to do so has been granted to such person by the proper official. Convictions for violations of the provisions of this article shall be punishable as provided in section 1-7. 
(Code 1981, § 7-8; Ord. No. O-05-15, § 1, 10-5-2015) 
Chapter 42 - DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 26; businesses, ch. 30; planning, ch. 90; special assessments, ch. 102; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 106; zoning, ch. 138. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 42-1-42-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - DOWNTOWN DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, adopted March 5, 2001, amended art. II in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, art. II, consisting of §§ 42-31-42-40 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 8-93, §§ 2-11, adopted October 18, 1993; Ord. No. O-1-97, § 2, adopted February 17, 1997. 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2. 
State Law reference- Downtown development authority, MCL 125.1651 et seq. 

Sec. 42-31. - Definitions. 
    The terms used in this article shall have the same meaning as given them in Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.), or as provided in this section, unless the context clearly indicates the contrary as used in this article: 
    Authority: The downtown development authority of the city created by this article. 
    Board or board of trustees: The board of trustees of the authority, the governing body of the authority. 
    Chief executive officer: The city manager. 
    City council or council: The city council of the City of Berkley. 
    Downtown district: The downtown district designated by this article, as now existing or hereafter amended. 
    Interest in property: A financial interest such that there is a responsibility to pay property taxes either directly as a property owner or indirectly through rent payments. 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
State Law reference- Definitions, MCL 125.1661. 
Sec. 42-32. - Determination of necessity. 
    The city council hereby determines that it is in the best interests of the city to halt property value deterioration and increase property tax valuation where possible in the downtown business district of the city, to eliminate the causes of that deterioration, and to promote economic growth by establishing a downtown development authority pursuant to Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001) 
State Law reference- Determination of necessity, MCL 125.1653. 
Sec. 42-33. - Creation of authority. 
    Pursuant to Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.), a downtown development authority is hereby created for the city. The authority shall be a public body corporate and shall be known and exercise its powers under the title of "Downtown Development Authority of the City of Berkley." The authority may adopt a seal, may sue and be sued in any court of this state, and shall possess all the powers necessary to carry out the purpose of its incorporation as provided by this article and Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.). The enumeration of a power in this article or in Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.) shall not be construed as a limitation upon the general powers of the authority. 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 5-3-2001) 
Sec. 42-34. - Description of downtown district. 
    The downtown district in which the authority shall exercise its powers, as provided by Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.), shall consist of the property in the city described on Exhibit A, as revised, which is on file in city hall, subject to such changes as may be made pursuant to this article and Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 5-3-2001) 
Sec. 42-35. - Board of trustees. 
(a)  Composition, appointment, membership. The authority shall be under supervision and control of a board of trustees consisting of the chief executive officer of the city and 12 members. The members shall be appointed by the chief executive officer subject to the approval of the city council. At least eight members shall be persons having an interest in property located in the downtown district. At least four of these members shall be from properties located on Coolidge and at least four from properties located on 12 Mile Road. At least two members shall be members at large without interest in property located in the downtown district. Each of the remaining two members may have interest in either 12 Mile or Coolidge property or be a member at large. The expiration of the term of each current trustee is extended from January 1 to June 30 of the same year. Thereafter, each appointment shall be for a term of four years. 
    An appointment to fill a vacancy shall be made by the chief executive officer for an unexpired term with the approval of city council. All members shall hold office until the member's successor is appointed and shall serve without compensation. Each member, however, shall be reimbursed by the downtown development authority for those actual and necessary expenses approved by the board and directly incurred in performance of their duties as board members. The chairperson of the board shall be elected by the board. Qualifications for members shall be as set forth in Public Act. No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.). 
(b)  Replacement of member. Pursuant to notice and after having been given an opportunity to be heard, a member of the board may be removed for cause by the city council. 
(c)  Development of action committees. The board of trustees shall not develop a political action committee or as a body endorse any city, county, state or national political candidates. 
(d)  Conflict of interest. Any member who has a financial interest, direct or indirect or by reason of ownership of stock in any corporation, in any contract with the city or in the sale of any land, material, supplies or services to the city or to a contractor supplying the city shall be governed by state law regarding conduct of public servants. 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001) 
Cross reference- Boards and Commissions generally, § 2-176 et seq. 
State Law reference- Contractual conflicts of interest, MCL 15.321 et seq.; public ethics, MCL 15.341 et seq.; board of trustees, MCL 125.1664. 
Sec. 42-36. - Powers of the authority. 
    Except as specifically otherwise provided by this article, the authority shall possess all powers to carry out the purposes of its incorporation and shall have all powers provided by Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.). 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001) 
Sec. 42-37. - Duties. 
    The downtown development authority may: 
(1)  Prepare an analysis of economic changes taking place in the downtown district. 
(2)  Study and analyze the impact of metropolitan growth upon the downtown district. 
(3)  Plan and propose the construction, renovation, repair, remodeling, rehabilitation, restoration, preservation or reconstruction of a public facility, an existing building, or a multiple-family dwelling unit which may be necessary or appropriate to the execution of a plan which, in the opinion of the board, aids in the economic growth of the downtown district. 
(4)  Develop long-range plans in cooperation with the city planning commission, designed to halt the deterioration of property values in the downtown district and to promote the economic growth of the downtown district, and take such steps as may be necessary to persuade property owners to implement the plans to the fullest extent possible. 
(5)  Implement any plan of development in the downtown district necessary to achieve the purposes of this article, in accordance with the powers of this authority as granted by this article. 
(6)  Make and enter into contracts necessary or incidental to the exercise of its powers and the performance of its duties. 
(7)  Acquire by purchase or otherwise, on terms and conditions and in a manner the authority deems proper, or own, convey, or otherwise dispose of, or lease as lessor or lessee, land and other property, real or personal, or rights or interests therein, which the authority determines is reasonably necessary to achieve the purposes of this article, and to grant or acquire licenses, easements and options with respect thereto. 
(8)  Improve land and construct, reconstruct, rehabilitate, restore and preserve, equip, improve, maintain, repair and operate any building, including multiple-family dwellings and any necessary or desirable appurtenances thereto, within the downtown district for the use, in whole or in part of any public or private person or corporation, or a combination thereof. 
(9)  Fix, charge and collect fees, rents and charges for the use of any building or property under its control or any part thereof, or facility therein, and pledge the fees, rents, and charges for the payment of revenue bonds issued by the authority. 
(10)  Lease any building or property under its control, or any part thereof. 
(11)  Accept grants and donations of property, labor or other things of value from a public or private source. 
(12)  Acquire and construct public facilities. 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 125.1657. 
Sec. 42-38. - Financing. 
(a)  The activities of the authority shall be financed from one or more of the following sources: 
(1)  Donations to the authority for the performance of its functions. 
(2)  Proceeds of a tax imposed pursuant to Public Act No. 197 of 1975, § 12 (MCL 125.1662). 
(3)  Monies borrowed and to be repaid s authorized by Public Act No. 197 of 1975, § 13 (MCL 125.1663). 
(4)  Revenues from any property, building or facility owned, leased, licensed or operated by the authority or under its control, subject to the limitations imposed upon the authority by trusts or other agreements. 
(5)  Proceeds of a tax increment financing plan. 
(6)  Proceeds from a special assessment district created as provided by law. 
(7)  Monies obtained from other sources approved by the city council. 
(8)  Monies received by the authority and not covered under subsection (a) of this section shall be immediately deposited to the credit of the authority, subject to disbursement pursuant to Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.). Except as provided in Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.), the city shall not oblige itself, nor shall it ever be obligated to pay any sums from public monies, other than monies received by the city pursuant to this section, for or on account of the activities of the authority. 
(b)  If a tax increment financing district is created, inflationary valuation growth on the existing tax base which is captured can be returned to each taxing authority proportional to the rate of inflation as recommended by the board of trustees and approved by the city council. 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, MCL 125.1661. 
Sec. 42-39. - Director; bond of director. 
    If a director is employed as authorized by Public Act No. 197 of 1975, § 12 (MCL 125.1655), he shall post bond in the penal sum of five thousand dollars as required by sections of Act 197. The premium of the bond shall be deemed an operating expense of the authority, payable from funds available to the authority for expenses of operation. 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001) 
State Law reference- Director, MCL 125.1655. 
Sec. 42-40. - Fiscal year; adoption of budget. 
(a)  The fiscal year of the authority shall begin on July 1 of each year and end on June 30 of the following year, or such other fiscal year as may hereafter be adopted by the city. 
(b)  The board shall annually prepare a budget and submit it to the city manager for submission to the council. The board shall not finally adopt a budget for any fiscal year until the budget has been approved by the council. The board may, however, temporarily adopt a budget in connection with the operation of any improvements which have been financed by revenue bonds where required to do so by the ordinance authorizing the revenue bonds. 
(c)  The authority shall submit financial reports to the council at the same time and on the same basis as departments of the city are required to submit reports. The authority shall be audited annually by the same independent auditors auditing the city, and copies of the audit report shall be filed with the council. 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001) 
Secs. 42-41-42-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DEVELOPMENT PLAN AND TAX INCREMENT FINANCING PLAN[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, adopted March 5, 2001, amended art. III in its entirety to read as herein set out. Formerly, art. III, §§ 42-71-42-79 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 4-96, §§ 1-9, adopted May 20, 1996. 

Sec. 42-7l. - General provisions. 
(a)  Findings. 
(1)  The development plan portion of the plan meets the requirements set forth in Public Act No. 195 of 1975, § 17(2) (MCL 125.1667(2)), and the tax increment financing plan portion of the plan meets the requirements set forth in Public Act No. 195 of 1975, § 14(2) (MCL 125.1664(2)). 
(2)  The proposed method of financing the development is feasible, and the authority has the ability to arrange the financing. 
(3)  The development is reasonable and necessary to carry out the purposes of Public Act No. 195 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.). 
(4)  Any land included within the development area to be acquired is reasonably necessary to carry out the purposes of Public Act No. 195 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.). 
(5)  The development plan portion of the plan is in reasonable accord with the master plan of the city. 
(6)  Public services, such as fire and police protection and utilities, are or will be adequate to service the development area. 
(7)  Changes in zoning, streets, street levels, intersections, and utilities, to the extent required by the plan, are reasonably necessary for the plan and for the city. 
(b)  Public purpose. The city council hereby determines that the plan constitutes a public purpose. 
(c)  Best interest of the public. The city council hereby determines that it is in the best interests of the public to halt property value deterioration, increase property tax valuation, eliminate the causes of the deterioration in property values, and to promote growth in the downtown district to proceed with the plan. 
Cross reference- Finance, § 2-106 et seq.; taxation, ch. 114. 
(d)  Approval and adoption of plan. The plan is hereby approved and adopted. A copy of the plan and all later amendments thereto shall be maintained on file in the city clerk's office. 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001) 
Sec. 42-72. - Expenditure of funds by authority; loans, leases or purchases. 
    The downtown development authority will not spend any funds outside of those authorized under Public Act No. 197 of 1975 (MCL 125.1651 et seq.), to date and annually approved through the budget process and shall not commit to any loans, leases or purchases without city council approval. 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001) 
Sec. 42-73. - Projects or purchases to have sufficient revenue sources. 
    The downtown development authority will not propose to the city council any projects or purchases without a sufficient revenue source to support the proposal. The proposal must be reviewed with comments by the city's auditors as to the stability of proposed resources. 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001) 
Sec. 42-74. - Master plan conflict with downtown development plan. 
    If it is determined that any portions of the city's master plan conflicts with the provisions of the downtown development plan, then the development plan shall be adopted as a component of the master plan pursuant to Public Act No. 285 of 1931, § 8 (MCL 125.38). 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001) 
Sec. 42-75. - Purchase or lease of real property. 
    The downtown development authority shall not purchase or lease any real property for a period of two years following the adoption of this article and thereafter only with council approval. 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001) 
Sec. 42-76. - Bidding procedures on purchases and contracts. 
    The downtown development authority shall follow the city's bidding procedures on purchases and contracts. 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001) 
Sec. 42-77. - Extension of tax increment financing plan. 
    The tax increment financing plan shall extend to May 20, 2021. 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001) 
Sec. 42-78. - Maximum indebtedness; description of projects and amounts to be financed; captured revenues. 
    The maximum amount of indebtedness to be incurred will not exceed $5,000,000.00 for projects identified in the development plan. A description of the various projects and the actual amounts expected to be financed are as set forth in the development plan. Revenues captured will be used to accomplish projects in the development area. 
(Ord. No. O-2-2001, § 1, 3-5-2001)

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 46-1. - Adoption of odd-year elections. 
    The city has determined to conform to Public Act No. 116 of 1954 (MCL 168.644a et seq., MSA 6.1644(1) et seq.), as amended, and provide for elections to be held on the Tuesday succeeding the first Monday in November in every odd-numbered year for all elective city officers. 
(Code 1981, § 8-1) 
Sec. 46-2. - Filing of nominating petitions. 
    Nominating petitions filed for offices to be filled at the odd-year general election shall be filed with the city clerk no later than 4:00 p.m. on the Tuesday succeeding the first Monday in August prior to the odd-year general election. 
(Code 1981, § 8-2)

(Ord. No. O-1-12, § 1, 3-5-2012) 
Chapter 50 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes:

ARTICLE II. - FIRE PREVENTION CODE 

Sec. 50-31. - Adoption of BOCA National Fire Prevention Code. 
    The BOCA National Fire Prevention Code, 1996 edition, as promulgated by Building Officials and Code Administrators International, Inc., is hereby adopted by the city including all fire control measures and regulations, as set forth in such BOCA Fire Code, for the purposes of controlling conditions which could impede or interfere with fire suppression forces. 
(Code 1981, § 10-14; Ord. No. O-11-97, § 1, 2-17-1997) 
State Law reference- Authority to adopt technical codes by reference, MCL 117.3(k), MSA 5.2073, (k). 
Sec. 50-32. - Code on file. 
    Complete printed copies of the 1996 BOCA National Fire Prevention Code, tenth edition, adopted in section 50-31 are available for public use and inspection at the offices of the city clerk and the director of community development/code official. 
(Code 1981, § 10-15; Ord. No. O-11-97, § 1, 2-17-1997) 
Sec. 50-33. - Blanks in code to be filled in. 
    The following blanks in the 1996 BOCA National Fire Prevention Code shall be filled in as follows: The words "the City of Berkley, Michigan" shall be inserted in the second line of section F-101.1 on page 3 of such code. 
(Code 1981, § 10-16; Ord. No. O-11-97, § 1, 2-17-1997) 
Sec. 50-34. - Changes in code. 
    The following articles and sections of the 1996 BOCA National Fire Prevention Code are hereby amended or deleted as set forth, and additional articles and sections are added as indicated. The article and section numbers refer to like articles and sections in the BOCA National Fire Prevention Code: 
Subsection F-107.3 is amended to read: 
"F-107.3(1) Inspection of premises. A city inspector shall periodically inspect all construction undertaken pursuant to a building permit issued by the code official or authorized representative to ensure that the construction is performed in accordance with requirements of the code and other applicable laws and ordinances." 
"F-107.3(2) Knowledge of required inspection; entry, time and manner; purposes of inspection; persons accompanying inspectors. The owner of the premises on which a building or structure is being constructed is deemed to have knowledge of the required inspection by the code official and of any construction being performed on it until a certificate of use and occupancy has been issued. An inspector, or a team of inspectors, on presentation of the proper credentials, may inspect the premises and construction thereon, unless entry is refused by the owner, for purposes of ensuring compliance with the building permit, the code and other applicable laws and regulations. An inspection shall be made between 8:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. on business days, or when construction is actually being undertaken, except if the code official has probable cause to believe that an immediate danger to life, limb or property exists, or except with permission of an owner, or his agent, architect, engineer or builder. An inspection pursuant to this section shall be solely for the purposes of enforcing this act and other laws and ordinances related to construction of buildings and structures. A person other than the owner, his agent, architect, engineer or builder shall not accompany an inspector or team of inspectors on an inspection, unless his presence is necessary for the enforcement of this ordinance, or other laws and ordinances related to construction of the building or structure, or except with the consent of an owner or his agent, architect, engineer or builder." 
(Code 1981, § 10-17; Ord. No. O-11-97, § 1, 2-17-1997) 
Sec. 50-35. - Adoption of Michigan Fire Prevention Code. 
    The latest regulations of the Fire Marshal Division of the Michigan State Police, known and cited as the Fire Prevention Code (MCL 29.1 et seq., MSA 4.559(1) et seq.), are hereby adopted by reference as a supplement to the 1996 BOCA National Fire Prevention Code. In case of conflict, the stricter regulations shall prevail. Complete printed copies of such regulations are available for public use and inspection in the offices of the city clerk and the director of community development/code official. 
(Code 1981, § 10-18; Ord. No. O-11-97, § 1, 2-17-1997) 
State Law reference- Adoption by reference, MCL 117.3(k), MSA 5.2073, (k). 
Sec. 50-36. - Licenses, permits and fees. 
    All licenses and permits required by the city, with respect to this article, shall be issued when the application for the same has been approved by the city manager or designee. The fees for such licenses and permits shall be as presently established or as hereafter prescribed by resolution of the city council. 
(Code 1981, § 10-19; Ord. No. O-11-97, § 1, 2-17-1997) 
Sec. 50-37. - Appeals. 
    The building code board of appeals shall have the authority to interpret the provisions of the fire codes adopted in this article and may, in specific cases, grant variances and exceptions to such code requirements, providing such variance or exception is in harmony with the general purpose and intent of the fire code requirements and are in compliance with Public Act No. 86 of 1945 (MCL 29.1 et seq., MSA 4.559(1) et seq.), as amended. 
(Code 1981, § 10-20; Ord. No. O-11-97, § 1, 2-17-1997) 
Sec. 50-38. - Nuisance per se. 
    Any building, structure or premises erected, used, occupied or maintained in violation of article is hereby declared to be a nuisance per se. Upon application to any court of competent jurisdiction, the court may order the nuisance abated or the violation, or threatened violation, restrained and enjoined. 
(Code 1981, § 10-21; Ord. No. O-11-97, § 1, 2-17-1997) 
Secs. 50-39-50-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - FIREWORKS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. O-5-13, § 1, adopted June 25, 2013, repealed former Art. III, §§ 50-71-50-77, and enacted a new Art. III as set out herein. Former Art. III pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. O-2-97, §§ 1(10-22)-1(10-28), 2-17-1997. 
Cross reference- Offenses against public safety, § 82-276 et seq. 
State Law reference- Fireworks, MCL 750.243a et seq., MSA 28.440(1) et seq. 

Sec. 50-71. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
    APA Standard 87-1 means 2001 APA Standard 87-1, standard for construction and approval for transportation of fireworks, novelties, and theatrical pyrotechnics, published by the American Pyrotechnics Association of Bethesda, Maryland. 
    Consumer fireworks means fireworks devices that are designed to produce visible effects by combustion, that are required to comply with the construction, chemical composition, and labeling regulations promulgated by the United States Consumer Product Safety Commission under 16 CFR parts 1500 and 1507, and that are listed in APA Standard 87-1, 3.1.2, 3.1.3, or 3.5. Consumer fireworks does not include low-impact fireworks. 
    Display fireworks means large fireworks devices that are explosive materials intended for use in fireworks displays and designed to produce visible or audible effects by combustion, deflagration, or detonation, as provided in 27 CFR 555.11, 49 CFR 172, and APA Standard 87-1, 4.1. 
    Firework or fireworks means any composition or device, except for a starting pistol, a flare gun, or a flare, designed for the purpose of producing a visible or audible effect by combustion, deflagration, or detonation. Fireworks consist of consumer fireworks, low-impact fireworks, articles pyrotechnic, display fireworks, and special effects. 
    Low-impact fireworks means ground and handheld sparkling devices as that phrase is defined under APA Standard 87-1, 3.1, 3.1.1.1 to 3.1.1.8, and 3.5. 
    Minor means an individual who is less than 18 years of age. 
    Sky lantern means a small, unmanned, untethered, balloon-like, free-floating aerial luminary, also known as a Chinese lantern, sky candle or fire balloon. Sky lanterns rely on an open flame suspended within or underneath the balloon to heat the air inside to provide lift. 
(Ord. No. O-5-13, § 2, 6-25-2013) 
Sec. 50-72. - Manufacture of fireworks. 
    The manufacture of fireworks is prohibited in the city. 
(Ord. No. O-5-13, § 2, 6-25-2013) 
Sec. 50-73. - Use of consumer fireworks and sky lanterns. 
(a)  The ignition, discharge and use of consumer fireworks is prohibited, except on the day preceding, the day of, or the day after a national holiday, as defined in 5 USC 6103. On those days, the ignition, discharge or use of consumer fireworks between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 8:00 a.m., or between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 8:00 a.m. on New Year's Day, is prohibited. 
(b)  A person shall not ignite, discharge or use consumer fireworks on public property, school property, church property, or the property of another person without that organization's or person's express permission to use those fireworks on those premises. 
(c)  The purchase of consumer fireworks at any time by a minor, or the possession and use of consumer fireworks by a minor except while under direct parental supervision, is prohibited. 
(d)  A person shall not discharge, ignite or use consumer fireworks or low-impact fireworks while under the influence of alcoholic liquor, a controlled substance, or a combination of alcoholic liquor and controlled substances. 
(e)  The ignition, discharge and use of sky lanterns are, at all times, prohibited in the city. 
(Ord. No. O-5-13, § 2, 6-25-2013) 
Sec. 50-74. - Display fireworks. 
    Use of display fireworks shall comply with the rules and regulations issued by the public safety department for the granting of permits for supervised public displays of fireworks. Every such use of display fireworks shall be under the control of a person competent to ensure compliance with all applicable laws, codes, rules and regulations and ensure proper safety precautions. The display fireworks shall be arranged, located, discharged or fired in a manner that, in the opinion of the public safety director will not be a hazard to property or endanger any person. 
(Ord. No. O-5-13, § 2, 6-25-2013) 
Sec. 50-75. - Exceptions. 
    Nothing in this article shall be construed to prohibit any of the following: 
(1)  A wholesaler, retailer, commercial manufacturer, or importer from selling, storing, using, transporting, or distributing consumer fireworks or low-impact fireworks. 
(2)  The use of fireworks by railroads or other transportation agencies or law enforcement agencies for signal purposes or illumination. 
(3)  The use of agricultural or wildlife fireworks. 
(4)  The sale or use of blank cartridges for any of the following: 
a.  A show or play. 
b.  Signal or ceremonial purposes in athletics or sports. 
c.  A show or play. 
d.  Signal or ceremonial purposes in athletics or sports. 
e.  Use by military organizations. 
f.  Use by law enforcement agencies. 
(5)  The possession, sale, or disposal of fireworks incidental to the public display of fireworks by wholesalers or other persons who possess a permit to possess, store, and sell explosives from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms, and Explosives of the United States Department of Justice. 
(6)  Interstate wholesalers from selling, storing, using, transporting, or distributing fireworks. 
(Ord. No. O-5-13, § 2, 6-25-2013) 
Sec. 50-76. - Seizure of illegal fireworks. 
    If the public safety department or law enforcement agency determines a violation of this article has occurred, the public safety department or law enforcement agency may seize the fireworks as evidence of the violation. Evidence seized under this subsection shall be stored pending disposition of any criminal or civil proceedings arising from a violation of this article at the expense of the person, if the person is found responsible or liable for the violation. 
(Ord. No. O-5-13, § 2, 6-25-2013) 
Chapter 54 - GARAGE/ESTATE SALES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 30; public auctions, § 30-546 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 54-1. - Violations. 
    Violations of this chapter shall be a municipal civil infraction and prosecuted consistent with the provisions of chapter 82, article IX, pertaining to municipal civil infractions. 
Secs. 54-2-54-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - GARAGE SALES 

Sec. 54-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Garage sale: Home sale, basement sale, attic sale, or other type of so-called residential sale of used tangible personal property such as, but not limited to, clothing, household effects, tools, garden implements, toys, recreation equipment or other used or secondhand items customarily found in and about the home and advertised in a manner whereby the public at large is, or can be, aware of such sale. 
(Code 1981, § 33-127(1)) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 54-32. - Permitted for homeowners and occupants. 
    A residential homeowner or occupant may conduct a garage sale on the premises as set forth in this article. 
(Code 1981, § 33-127) 
Sec. 54-33. - Applicability of article. 
    This article shall not apply to the householder who, during the normal course of housekeeping, advertises or otherwise offers for sale individual pieces of furniture or an appliance of value being replaced or no longer needed. 
(Code 1981, § 33-127(6)) 
Sec. 54-34. - Permit required. 
    A homeowner or occupant shall first obtain a permit from the city clerk before conducting any garage sale. There shall be no fee or charge for the issuance of the permit. 
(Code 1981, § 33-127(2)) 
Cross reference- Licenses and permits generally, § 30-31 et seq. 
Sec. 54-35. - Limitations as to duration, frequency and location. 
    Each garage sale shall be limited to three consecutive days of operation and no more than two such sales may be conducted by any household or member thereof per calendar year. No sale shall be conducted before 9:00 a.m. or after 7:00 p.m. each day. No sale shall be conducted out of doors. 
(Code 1981, § 33-127(3)) 
Sec. 54-36. - Signs. 
    No more than two signs of four square feet each in area and placed at least 12 feet within the property lines shall be used to advertise a garage sale, and such signs shall be removed immediately after the garage sale. No other signs pertaining to a garage sale shall be permitted on public or private property. 
(Code 1981, § 33-127(4)) 
Cross reference- Advertising, ch. 6; signs, ch. 94. 
Sec. 54-37. - Organizing parties; additional merchandise. 
    No person other than the homeowner or occupant shall conduct a garage sale (so-called), and no merchandise of any nature shall be brought in from any other source to supplement such sale. 
(Code 1981, § 33-127(5)) 
Chapter 58 - GARBAGE, RUBBISH AND REFUSE[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL

ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Authority to provide garbage disposal system, MCL 123.362, 324.4301. 

Sec. 58-31. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Building refuse: Waste materials from the demolition, construction, remodeling and repair operations on residences, stores and other buildings. 
    Garbage: All refuse and waste materials attendant to the preparation, dressing, cooking of or the use and storage of food for human consumption. 
    Industrial refuse: Waste materials resulting from industrial and manufacturing operations or processes of every nature whatsoever, including refuse material resulting from cleaning up in connection with such operations and processes. 
    Institutional-type containers: Containers constructed of steel with tightfitting covers of the same material equipped with wheels for ease of handling, with a capacity of not less than one cubic yard and adaptable for loading on city packer-type trucks, such container to meet all city, state and federal safety standards and requirements. 
    Person: Any individual, firm, owner, occupant, tenant, corporation, partnership or person in charge of the premises. 
    Rubbish: Combustible or noncombustible solid waste materials, other than garbage, including paper, rags, ashes, bottles, cans, cardboard boxes, shoes, clothing, broken dishes and other similar discarded material all of which shall be placed in plastic bags, metal garbage containers or other approved containers with handles and weigh not more than 60 pounds of such size to be easily handled by one man and capable of being loaded into a packer-type truck. All discarded newspapers and magazines shall be tied into bundles weighing not more than 60 pounds and placed at curbside. 
    Special pickup: Household or institutional items such as mattresses, refrigerators, hot water tanks, stoves, dryers, television sets, batteries, mufflers, bicycles, radios, household furniture, downspouting, rugs, toys and similar items which are to be collected as part of the regular garbage and refuse service and disposed of with no additional cost to the person. The term "special pickup" does not include automobiles, dirt, broken concrete, sand, tree trunks and logs above three inches in diameter, automobile engines and other similar items. Such described material shall be collected and hauled away by the person's own private contractor or hauler. Only as a last resort shall the city pick up and dispose of such items and only then upon payment of a specific charge as may be determined from time to time by resolution of the city council. 
    Yard refuse: Leaves, grass clippings, lawn rakings, garden vegetation and weeds free of other debris or refuse. 
(Code 1981, § 12-16) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-32. - Rules and regulations of city manager to implement article provisions. 
    In order to clarify and implement the provisions of this article, the city manager is hereby authorized and directed to make all necessary and reasonable rules and regulations consistent with this article. 
(Code 1981, § 12-17) 
Sec. 58-33. - Responsibility for storage. 
    The city shall not and does not assume responsibility for any municipal refuse and special pickups until they are collected by the city. Until that time, the producer is responsible for the proper storage of the material and for the proper preparation of the refuse for collection. No person shall permit outside residents to bring any items into the city for pickup. 
(Code 1981, § 12-18) 
Sec. 58-34. - Containers. 
    No person shall permit to accumulate upon his premises any garbage or rubbish unless it is placed and maintained in containers as follows: 
(1)  Containers for garbage. All containers used for garbage shall be substantial metal, plastic or rubber construction, provided with handles and a tight fitting cover. They shall have a capacity of not more than 32 gallons and shall weigh not more than 60 pounds when filled. The cover shall be kept on whenever garbage is placed in the container. Plastic bags shall be deemed a suitable container for solid waste if they are securely sealed (not punctured) and are filled so that the contents will not cause tearing or rupturing of the bag when it is lifted at the sealed or tied end. 
(2)  Containers for rubbish. Containers for rubbish shall be of substantial metal, plastic or rubber construction to permit handling and large enough to prevent the scattering of materials. They shall weigh not more than 60 pounds when full. 
(3)  Containers for yard refuse. 
a.  Tree limbs, branches, shrubbery and bush cuttings and other brush not exceeding one-half inch in diameter shall be placed in either two-mil plastic bags or approved containers used for regular refuse collection or shall be cut into three-foot lengths and tied into bundles not exceeding 60 pounds. Such material shall be placed at curbside for regular trash pickup service. All tree trimmings, 
branches and limbs in excess of one-half inch in diameter, but not exceeding four inches in diameter, and from three feet to ten feet long, shall be placed at curbside in front of the premises with butt ends all facing in one direction for disposal by the chipper machine as part of the regular city service. All tree trunks, logs, branches, rootballs, stumps and other similar parts of a tree more than four inches in diameter shall be removed from the city by the owner, occupant or person in charge of the premises at his cost. 
b.  When an owner, occupant or person in charge of the premises uses a tree removal contractor, such contractor shall remove such trees from the city at his cost and fully comply with all applicable ordinances. 
(4)  Institutional-type containers. Institutional-type containers shall be constructed of steel with appropriate covers and equipped with wheels for ease of handling, with a capacity of not less than one cubic yard and adaptable for loading on packer-type trucks. 
(5)  Broken containers. Containers that are broken or fail to meet the requirement of this section may be classified as rubbish, and after due notice to the owner, collected as such. 
(6)  Location of containers. Containers shall not be placed under the eaves of any building in such a manner as to permit water to enter them, and any container filled or partially filled with ice or water will not be emptied. 
(Code 1981, § 12-19; Ord. No. 6-94, § 1, 3-21-1994; Ord. No. O-16-01, § 1, 10-15-2001) 
Sec. 58-35. - Collection by contracting private company; charges; schedule; containers supplied. 
(a)  The city shall contract with a private company for the purpose of refuse collection. Services performed pursuant to a contract for refuse collection shall include the following: 
(1)  Garbage and rubbish; 
(2)  Special pickups; and 
(3)  Commingled recyclables. 
(b)  Refuse collected by the contractor upon payment of a specific charge as determined by resolution of the city council shall include the following: 
(1)  All garbage and rubbish from apartments, condominiums and all nonresidential sources to the extent that the average unit cost of such service exceeds the unit cost of such service to single-family residences. 
(2)  Bulky items defined as not being included in the special pickup category. 
(c)  The city and contractor shall arrange a schedule for the collections of garbage and rubbish and for special pickups once each week from each residence or place of business in the several parts of the city. The contractor shall provide the necessary labor and equipment for such collection in accordance with its contract. 
(d)  The city may provide two-mil thick plastic bags for garbage and rubbish use at the sole cost of the person requesting the same. 
(Code 1981, § 12-20; Ord. No. 6-94, § 1, 3-21-1994) 
Cross reference- Businesses, ch. 30. 
Sec. 58-36. - Building refuse. 
(a)  Building refuse shall be collected and disposed of by the building or demolition contractor. 
(b)  Dumpsters or storage bins (e.g. PODS) shall be used on a temporary basis. If a building permit has been issued, a dumpster or bin may be installed on the property during the time that the building permit is valid. If a building permit is not required by the city, then a dumpster or bin may be installed on the property for a period not to exceed three months. 
(c)  The dumpster or bin shall be placed on a hard surface. The placement shall not constitute a sight obstruction. 
(d)  Whenever a dumpster or bin is in violation, it shall be considered as though it were a nuisance and the process for abating including ticketing or the city's removal of the dumpster or bin shall adhere to Chapter 78 Nuisances. 
(Ord. No. 1-95, § 1, 3-6-1995; Ord. No. O-07-09, § 1, 7-20-2009) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 26. 
Sec. 58-37. - Industrial refuse. 
    Industrial refuse shall not be collected by the city but shall be the responsibility of the industry. 
(Code 1981, § 12-22) 
Sec. 58-38. - Rules and regulations for property owners and occupants. 
(a)  It shall be the duty of each person to place all garbage and rubbish in proper containers on the outside of the sidewalk in front of their premises no earlier than 24 hours prior to collection, and all empty containers shall be removed from the street no later than midnight on the same day that the collection is made. Containers shall not be placed on front porches, front drives or front yards prior to placement for pickup. The code enforcement officer shall have the authority to approve an alternative location of refuse containers. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of each owner, operator or person in charge of gas and service stations, garages or other places of business that handle automobile tires and mufflers to accumulate no more than 12 wornout tires on the premises nor more than six mufflers at one time. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of each owner, operator or person in charge of any institutional-type metal container to have on the premises only those containers that meet city, state and federal safety standards and requirements. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to rake, sweep, deposit, place or in any manner cause to be placed leaves in the traveled portion of the public street at any time other than the months of October and November of each year. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to commingle grass clippings and yard waste with garbage or rubbish. 
(f)  It shall be the duty of each property owner to adhere to the refuse rules and regulations as amended and approved by the public works department. 
(g)  Violations of this section shall be a municipal civil infraction and prosecuted consistent with the provisions of chapter 82, article IX, pertaining to municipal civil infractions. 
(Code 1981, § 12-23; Ord. No. 6-94, § 1, 3-21-1994; Ord. No. O-16-01, § 1, 10-15-2001) 
Sec. 58-39. - Tampering with containers. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, other than the owner or occupant, his employees or agents, city employees, or a private collector to tamper or meddle with any garbage container or bundle or remove the contents thereof from the location where the same have been properly placed pending collection. 
(Code 1981, § 12-24) 
Sec. 58-40. - Scavenging. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to scavenge, take or pick out or sort in any way any garbage or rubbish materials or other discarded items after they have been set out at the curb or sidewalk for disposal and city collection. Violation of this section shall be a municipal civil infraction. 
(Code 1981, § 12-26; Ord. No. 3-95, § 1, 3-6-1995; Ord. No. O-07-15, § 1, 1-4-2016) 
Sec. 58-41. - Burning. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to burn or allow to be burned in the open on any public or private ground within the city any leaves, garbage, rubbish, refuse, trees, stumps, tires or materials of any kind which exude obnoxious odors, smoke or other matter as is, or is likely to be injurious to the public health or welfare, except the burning of such solid wastes is permitted in approved domestic incinerators installed within a residence or other building on the premises. Industrial and commercial wastes and refuse may be burned within the city in incinerators approved by the air pollution control section of the state department of health and in accordance with the state air pollution control rules and regulations, effective August 15, 1967, which further prohibits open burning and limits emissions from such incinerators. 
(Code 1981, § 12-25; Ord. No. 43-95, § 1, 3-6-1995) 
Cross reference- Fire prevention and protection, ch. 50. 
Sec. 58-42. - Charges. 
    All fees and specific charges required in connection with this article shall be as set out and as may be amended from time to time by simple resolution of city council. 
(Code 1981, § 12-27) 
Secs. 58-43-58-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - COMPOST 

Sec. 58-71. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Compost: A dark, crumbly and earthy-smelling form of decomposing organic matter (lawn debris, yard waste, coffee grounds or tea leaves), also called humus. Compost is the result of the composting process. 
    Compost bin: A receptacle for a compost pile designed and constructed to facilitate composting. 
    Compost pile: An accumulation of compost. 
    Composting: Reduction of organic waste to humus. 
(Ord. No. 5-94, § 1(31-50), 4-4-1994) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 58-72. - Composting of lawn debris. 
    Lawn debris may be stored in a compost pile or compost bin meeting the requirements of this article. 
(Ord. No. 5-94, § 1(31-51), 4-4-1994) 
Sec. 58-73. - Permitted composting; nuisances; abatement. 
(a)  Compost piles shall be permitted only in accordance with the following: 
(1)  Compost piles shall be located only in a rear yard a minimum of one foot from any lot line and 15 feet from any dwelling located on adjacent property. 
(2)  Compost piles shall not exceed four feet by eight feet or eight feet in diameter, and shall not exceed four feet in height. Double compost piles may be utilized, provided that the total size does not exceed the provisions of this subsection (a). 
(3)  Compost piles and compost bins may include a combination of yard, garden and lawn debris such as leaves, weeds, branches, bark, stalks, stems, fruit and vegetable peelings, spent flowers, brush vines, wood ashes and coffee grounds. A commercial compost additive may be included as part of the process. 
(4)  Compost piles and compost bins shall not include meats, dairy products, vegetable oils, cooked foods, manure, dead fish (including bones or entrails), bones from meat or poultry, plastics, synthetics or other nonbiodegradable materials, and shells from nuts. 
(5)  The proper ratio of combined material shall be 25 percent green materials (such as grass clippings), 50 percent brown materials (such as leaves or straw), and 25 percent soil or compost. The soil adds essential microorganisms and accelerates the process of decomposition. 
(6)  Compost piles and compost bins shall be maintained to prevent the attraction and harborage of rodents and pests, and to prevent unpleasant odors. 
(b)  Compost piles and compost bins which do not conform to this section shall constitute a nuisance per se and may be abated by order of a court of competent jurisdiction in addition to any other applicable penalties. 
(Ord. No. 5-94, § 1(31-52), 4-4-1994) 
Cross reference- Nuisances generally, ch. 78.

ARTICLE II. - VOLUNTEER POLICE RESERVE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Law enforcement officer employment standards, MCL 28.601 et seq., MSA 4.450(1) et seq. 

Sec. 62-16. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a police reserve unit. 
(Code 1981, § 22.5-16) 
Sec. 62-17. - Composition; qualifications. 
    Consistent with the city's policy providing for equal opportunity, the police reserve unit shall be made up of persons who, at the time of their appointment, shall be residents or business owners in the city, and who have actually resided or owned a business for not less than six months prior to appointment. Each member shall be in good physical condition and of good character and not less than 21 years of age. The number of members of the reserve shall be set within budgetary guidelines and determined by the city manager and public safety director. This number may be amended on an annual basis. 
(Code 1981, § 22.5-17; Ord. No. 10-93, § 1, 1-3-1994) 
Sec. 62-18. - Appointment. 
    Appointments to the police reserve shall be made by the city manager upon the recommendation of the director of public safety. 
(Code 1981, § 22.5-18) 
Sec. 62-19. - Oath; commissions. 
    The police reserve unit shall function under the immediate direction of the public safety director, or, in the absence of the public safety director, the senior duty officer. Before entering upon the duties of a reserve police officer, each member shall take and subscribe to the same oath or affirmation as provided by statute to be taken and subscribed by all municipal officers. After subscribing the oath of office, each member of the police reserve unit shall be issued an official commission card signed by the public safety director and attested by the city clerk. 
(Code 1981, § 22.5-19) 
Sec. 62-20. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  Except during any period of probation, members of the police reserve unit shall have the power of enforcement of municipal ordinances of this city. All police reserve unit members, both regular and probationary, shall be subject to such rules and regulations governing the police reserve as shall be promulgated by the director of public safety and filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(b)  Membership in the police reserve unit shall not constitute membership in the regularly constituted public safety department, nor shall any member of the police reserve unit be entitled to any right or privilege of members of the regularly constituted public safety department, nor to any other prerequisite or emolument attaching to membership in the regularly constituted public safety department, excepting such state workmen's compensation benefits to which they may be entitled by law. 
(c)  Except as provided in subsection (a) of this section, the appointment of an individual as a reserve police officer under this article is not to be construed as providing any additional powers of arrest other than that enumerated in this article or granted under any statute of this state applicable to volunteer reserve police officers, nor shall the provisions of this article be construed to grant authority or power to carry weapons contrary to the statutory provisions of this state. 
(Code 1981, § 22.5-20) 
Sec. 62-21. - Compensation. 
    No member of the police reserve unit shall receive any compensation from the city for services as a member of the police reserve unit. 
(Code 1981, § 22.5-21) 
Chapter 66 - LIBRARY[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 106. 
State Law reference- Libraries generally, MCL 397.201 et seq., MSA 15.1661 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 66-1-66-15. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - LIBRARY BOARD[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Boards and commissions, § 2-176 et seq. 

Sec. 66-16. - Created. 
    There is hereby created a library board. 
(Code 1981, § 13-16) 
Sec. 66-17. - Composition. 
    The library board shall consist of five members. 
(Code 1981, § 13-17) 
Sec. 66-18. - Appointment; qualifications. 
    The members of the library board shall be appointed by a majority vote of the city council. No person shall be eligible to appointment who is not a citizen of the United States, a resident of the city or a registered voter. 
(Code 1981, § 13-18) 
Sec. 66-19. - Term of office. 
    The term of office of members of the library board shall be five years commencing July 1 in each year. Each year one member's term of office shall expire, and annually one member shall be appointed for the term of five years. 
(Code 1981, § 13-19) 
Sec. 66-20. - Compensation. 
    Members of the library board shall serve without compensation. 
(Code 1981, § 13-20) 
Sec. 66-21. - Removals from office. 
    Members of the library board shall be subject to removal from office by the council without cause assigned. 
(Code 1981, § 13-21) 
Sec. 66-22. - Filling of vacancies. 
    Any vacancy on the library board shall be filled by the council for the remainder of the unexpired term after considering recommendations from the library board. 
(Code 1981, § 13-22) 
Sec. 66-23. - Officers and library director. 
    The library board shall select a chairman, vice-chairman and a secretary from among its members. The library board shall recommend the selection of a library director to the city manager, when a vacancy occurs, who may consider such recommendation when filling such position pursuant to the merit system of personnel management. 
(Code 1981, § 13-23) 
Sec. 66-24. - Meetings and records; quorum. 
    The library board shall hold meetings regularly, at least once each month, and shall designate the time and place thereof by public notice. All meetings of the board shall be open to the public and held in a place available to the general public. The board shall adopt its own rules of procedure and shall keep a record of each meeting by the keeping of minutes, which minutes shall be filed with the city clerk not only to be made available for public inspection, but also transmitted to the city council and the city manager. Three members shall constitute a quorum for the transaction of business, and a lesser number may adjourn any meeting at which a quorum is not present. 
(Code 1981, § 13-24) 
Sec. 66-25. - Functions. 
    The library board shall act as a fact-finding and advisory body in conformity with the city charter and this Code to give recommendations and advice to the city council and the city manager about present and future needs regarding library functions, activities, buildings and grounds. 
(Code 1981, § 13-25) 
Sec. 66-26. - Expenses and obligation. 
    Neither the library board nor any of its members shall incur any expense or create any liability upon the city. If any expenditure of city funds may be required relative to the functioning of the library board, a request for expenditure shall be submitted to the city manager for approval before such funds are expended. 
(Code 1981, § 13-26) 
Chapter 70 - MOBILE HOMES, TRAILERS AND RECREATIONAL VEHICLES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 26; planning, ch. 90; soil erosion and sedimentation control, ch. 98; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 106; subdivision and combination of land, ch. 110; utilities, ch. 126; vegetation, ch. 130; zoning, ch. 138; mobile homes in single-family districts, § 138-298. 
State Law reference- Mobile home commission act, MCL 125.1101 et seq., MSA 19.855(1) et seq.; trailer coaches located outside licensed parks, MCL 125.741 et seq., MSA 5.278(21) et seq. 

Sec. 70-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Mobile home: As defined in the "Mobile Home Commission Act," (MCL 125.1101 et seq., MSA 19.855(1) et seq.). 
    Recreational vehicles: 
(1)  Boats and boat trailers which shall include boats, floats and rafts, plus the normal equipment to transport the same on the highway; 
(2)  Folding tent trailer which is a folding structure, mounted on wheels and designed for travel and vacation use; 
(3)  Motorized home which is a portable dwelling designed and constructed as an integral part of a self-propelled vehicle; 
(4)  Pickup camper which is a structure designed primarily to be mounted on a pickup or truck chassis and with sufficient equipment to render it suitable for use as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreational and vacation uses; 
(5)  Travel trailer which is a vehicular, portable structure built on a chassis, designed to be used as a temporary dwelling for travel, recreational and vacation uses, permanently identified as a travel trailer by the manufacturer or a movable or portable dwelling, eight feet or less in width by 33 feet or less in length constructed to be towed on its own chassis and connected to utilities and designed without a permanent foundation for yearround living; and 
(6)  Utility trailer which is a vehicle used to transport motorcycles, snowmobiles, go-carts or stock cars. 
(Code 1981, § 16-1) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 70-2. - Public parking. 
    No person shall park or permit the parking of any mobile home or recreational vehicle upon any public highway, street, alley, park or other public place within the city. Emergency or temporary parking or stopping may be permitted on any street, alley or highway subject to any other and further prohibitions, regulations or limitations imposed by the traffic and parking regulations for that street, alley or highway. 
(Code 1981, § 16-2; Ord. No. 7-95, § 1, 3-6-1995) 
Sec. 70-3. - Parking outside of licensed park. 
(a)  No person shall park or permit the parking of any unoccupied mobile home or recreational vehicle outside of a duly licensed mobile home park, except the parking of unoccupied recreational vehicles holding a current state license or mobile home in any accessory private garage building, or in any rear yard, is permitted, provided no living quarters shall be maintained or any business practiced in such trailers; provided, however, that nothing contained in this section shall be construed to hinder or prevent any person from loading, unloading or engaging in the business of handling mobile homes or recreational vehicles for sale or resale or for storage, subject to such regulations as may be prescribed by this Code relative to zoning or regulation of such business. 
(b)  The board of zoning appeals may grant variances from this section in accordance with the provisions of section 138-611. 
(Code 1981, § 16-2; Ord. No. 8-95, § 1, 3-6-1995) 
Sec. 70-4. - Permit for temporary occupancy required. 
    A permit for the occupancy of a mobile home or recreational vehicle may be granted for a period of time not exceeding four weeks, on a residence lot in conjunction with an occupied permanent residence, provided that the occupant of such mobile home or recreational vehicle is a friend or a relative of the occupant of such permanent residence and be a visiting guest and not a guest for hire. Written consent shall be obtained from and signed by the occupant of the main dwelling on such residence lot, giving consent for the use of the sanitary facilities of such main dwelling. Such permits shall be secured from the director of public safety. Application for such permit shall be made within 24 hours after placing such mobile home or recreational vehicle on such premises on such forms as shall be prescribed by the director of public safety. Such permit shall limit the duration of stay to a period of time not to exceed four weeks, and such permit shall not be renewed for a period of 12 months after its expiration. 
(Code 1981, § 16-4) 
Sec. 70-5. - Enforcement of chapter provisions. 
    In addition to the penalty applicable to a violation of this Code, any person parking, occupying or using any mobile home or recreational vehicle parked in violation of this chapter or any person maintaining or operating any mobile home or trailer camp in violation of this chapter or in violation of any regulation of the city health officer or of any statute of the state pertaining to mobile home or trailer camp shall be guilty of maintaining a nuisance per se, and, upon application by the city to any court of competent jurisdiction, the maintenance of such nuisance may be restrained and enjoined. 
(Code 1981, § 16-5) 
Chapter 74 - NOISE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Loudspeakers at drive-in restaurants, § 30-383; horn blowing and loud noises at drive-in restaurants, § 30-384; noise by peddlers and solicitors to attract attention, § 30-434; nuisances, ch. 78; offenses against public peace, § 82-151 et seq. 

Sec. 74-1. - Prohibition generally. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to make, continue or cause to be made or continued any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise or any noise which either annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health, peace or safety of others, within the limits of the city. 
(b)  Each of the acts enumerated in this chapter is declared unlawful and prohibited, but this enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive. 
(Code 1981, § 17-1) 
Sec. 74-2. - Exceptions to chapter provisions. 
    None of the terms or prohibitions of this chapter shall apply to or be enforced against: 
(1)  Emergency vehicles. Any police or fire vehicle or any ambulance while engaged upon emergency business; and 
(2)  Highway maintenance and construction. Excavations or repairs of bridges, streets or highways by or on behalf of the city or the state during the night, when the public safety, welfare and convenience renders it impossible to perform such work during the day. 
(Code 1981, § 17-2) 
Sec. 74-3. - Shouting and whistling. 
    Yelling, shouting, hooting, whistling or singing or the making of any other loud noise on the public street, between the hours of 11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., or the making of any such noise at any time so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any school, place of worship or office, or in any dwelling, hotel or other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity is prohibited. 
(Code 1981, § 17-3) 
Sec. 74-4. - Radio and musical instruments. 
    The playing of any radio, television set, phonograph or any musical instrument in such a manner or with such volume, particularly during the hours between 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., or at any time or place, so as to annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office or in any dwelling, hotel or other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity is prohibited. 
(Code 1981, § 17-4) 
Sec. 74-5. - Horns and signal devices. 
    The sounding of any horn or signal device on any automobile, motorcycle, bus or other vehicle while not in motion, except as a danger signal if another vehicle is approaching, apparently out of control, or to give warning of intent to get under motion, or if in motion, only as a danger signal after or as brakes are being applied and deceleration of the vehicle is intended, the creation by means of any such signal device of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound, and the sounding of such device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time, is prohibited. 
(Code 1981, § 17-5) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 122. 
Sec. 74-6. - Engine exhausts. 
    The discharge into the open air of the exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine or motor vehicle, except through a muffler or other device which effectively prevents loud or explosive noises therefrom, is prohibited. 
(Code 1981, § 17-6) 
Cross reference- Traffic and vehicles, ch. 122. 
Sec. 74-7. - Handling merchandise. 
    The creation of a loud and excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle or the opening and destruction of bales, boxes, crates and containers is prohibited. 
(Code 1981, § 17-7) 
Sec. 74-8. - Whistle or siren. 
    The blowing of any whistle or siren, except to give notice of the time to begin or stop work or as a warning of fire or danger, is prohibited. 
(Code 1981, § 17-8) 
Sec. 74-9. - Blowers. 
    The discharge into the open air of air from any noise-creating blower or power fan, unless the noise from such blower or fan is muffled sufficient to deaden such noise, is prohibited. 
(Code 1981, § 17-9) 
Sec. 74-10. - Construction. 
    The erection (including excavating therefor), demolition, alteration or repair of any building and the excavation of streets, highways and public or private areas is prohibited on Sundays except between the hours of 9:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m., and is prohibited other days except between the hours of 7:00 a.m. and 6:00 p.m. unless a permit is first obtained from the city manager. 
(Code 1981, § 17-10) 
Cross reference- Buildings and building regulations, ch. 26. 
Sec. 74-11. - Sound amplifiers. 
    It shall be unlawful to use any loudspeaker, amplifier or other instrument or device mounted on a vehicle or within a vehicle for any purpose except by speakers in the course of a public address which is noncommercial in character and, when so used, shall be subject to the following restrictions: 
(1)  Only after registration with the department of public safety for each separate occasion of use. 
(2)  The only sounds permitted are music or human speech. 
(3)  Operations are permitted for six hours each day, except on Sundays and legal holidays, when no operations shall be authorized. Election day shall not constitute a legal holiday within the meaning of this section. The permitted six hours of operation shall be within the hours of 10:30 a.m. and 1:30 p.m., and between the hours of 4:00 p.m. and 7:00 p.m. 
(4)  Sound-amplifying equipment mounted on vehicles shall not be operated unless the sound truck upon which such equipment is mounted is operated at a speed of at least ten miles per hour except when the truck is stopped or impeded by traffic. Where stopped by traffic, the sound-amplifying equipment shall not be operated for longer than one minute at each stop. 
(5)  Sound shall not be issued within 100 yards of hospitals, schools, churches or courthouses. 
(6)  The volume of sound shall be controlled so that it will not be audible for a distance in excess of 40 feet from the sound-amplifying equipment and so that the volume is not unreasonably loud, raucous, jarring, disturbing or a nuisance to the persons within the area of audibility. 
(7)  No sound-amplifying equipment shall be operated with an excess of 15 watts of power in the last state of amplification. 
Sec. 74-12. - Volume of radios and televisions. 
(a)  No person shall operate a radio or television unless the volume of sound shall be controlled so that it will not be audible for a distance of 40 feet from the device and so that the volume is not unreasonably loud, raucous, jarring, disturbing or a nuisance to persons within the area of audibility. 
(b)  No person shall suffer or permit any radio or television located on premises under his care, custody or control to be operated in violation of subsection (a) of this section. 
Chapter 78 - NUISANCES[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Charter reference- Hazards and nuisances, § 12.17. 
Cross reference- Animals deemed public nuisances, § 22-6; composting nuisances, § 58-73; noise, ch. 74; noxious weeds, § 130-76 et seq.; zoning performance standards, § 138-126 et seq. 

Sec. 78-1. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Nuisance : Any person doing an unlawful act, or omitting to perform a duty, or suffering or permitting any condition or thing to be or exist, which act, omission, condition or thing either: 
(1)  Injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health or safety of others; 
(2)  Offends decency; 
(3)  Is offensive to the senses; 
(4)  Unlawfully interferes with, obstructs or tends to obstruct or renders dangerous for passage any public or private street, highway, sidewalk, stream, ditch or drainage; 
(5)  In any way renders other persons insecure in life or the use of property; 
(6)  Essentially interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of life and property, or tends to depreciate the value of the property of others; or 
(7)  Tends to attract rodents or nuisance birds, such as pigeons, crows, seagulls, starlings or causes overcrowding of birds. 
(Code 1981, § 18-1; Ord. No. O-01-16, § 1, 2-1-2016) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 78-2. - Illustrative enumeration. 
    The maintaining, using, placing, depositing, leaving or permitting to be or remain on any public or private property of any of the following items, conditions or actions are hereby declared to be and constitute a nuisance; provided, however, that this enumeration shall not be deemed or construed to be conclusive, limiting or restrictive: 
(1)  Noxious weeds and other rank vegetation. 
(2)  The storage upon any property of building materials unless there is in force a valid building permit issued by the city for construction upon such property and such building materials are intended for use in connection with such construction; building materials shall include, but shall not be limited to, lumber, bricks, concrete or cinder blocks, plumbing materials, electrical wiring or equipment, shingles, mortar, concrete or cement, nails, screws, or any other materials used in constructing any structure (all unused building materials shall be removed from the premises by the contractor prior to issuance of any occupancy permit or final acceptance by the building inspector). 
(3)  The storage or accumulation of junk, trash, rubbish or refuse of any kind, except domestic refuse stored in such a manner as not to create a nuisance. The term "junk" shall include parts of machinery or motor vehicles, unused stoves or other appliances stored in the open, remnants of wood, metal or any other material or other castoff material of any kind whether or not the material could be put to any reasonable use. 
(4)  Storage on any property of junk vehicles except in a completely enclosed building; for the purpose of this chapter the term "junk vehicles" shall include any motor vehicle which is inoperative for any reason such as being in a state of disassembly, disrepair, stripped, dismantled, unregistered or unlicensed. No vehicle shall undergo major overhaul or body work in a residential district of this city. 
(5)  The outdoor or open storage of any salable material, equipment or merchandise on any property, where such open storage is permitted in this city, shall be placed, stored or stacked in such a manner that it is not dangerous to human life or otherwise hazardous to the general public safety or welfare. If such hazardous conditions exist they are hereby deemed to be a public nuisance and unsafe and the city manager or his designee shall cause immediate compliance to remove the unsafe conditions. Further, the outdoor or open storage of any material, equipment, products, or merchandise on any property in this city, where such storage is permitted, shall be screened from public view, from a public street, and from adjoining properties not of a similar nature, by an enclosure consisting of an obscuring wall, as approved by the building inspector, so as to reduce or mitigate any blighting effects on the surrounding area. 
(6)  The existence of any structure or damaged partial structure which because of fire, wind or other natural disaster, or physical deterioration is no longer habitable if a dwelling, nor useful of any other purpose for which it may have been intended. 
(7)  The existence of any vacant building, garage or other outbuilding unless such buildings are kept securely locked, windows kept glazed or neatly boarded up and otherwise protected to prevent entrance thereto by vandals. 
(8)  The existence of any incomplete structures unless such structure is in the course of construction in accordance with a valid and subsisting building permit issued by the city and unless such construction is completed within a reasonable time. 
(9)  Any condition which provides harborage for rats, mice, snakes and other vermin. 
(10)  Any building material, containers, machinery, junk, raw materials, and similar items shall be stored on a paved surface or at least 18 inches above the ground, to prevent harborage for rats, mice, snakes and other vermin. 
(11)  All unnecessary or unauthorized noises and annoying vibrations, including animal noises. 
(12)  All disagreeable or obnoxious odors and stenches, as well as the conditions, substances or other causes which give rise to the emission or generation of such odors and stenches. 
(13)  The carcasses of animals or fowl not disposed of within a reasonable time after death. 
(14)  The pollution of any public well or cistern, stream, lake, canal or body of water by sewage, dead animals, creamery, industrial wastes or other substances. 
(15)  Any building, structure or other place or location where any activity which is in violation of local, state or federal law is conducted, performed or maintained. 
(16)  Any accumulation of stagnant water permitted or maintained on any lot or piece of ground. 
(17)  Dense smoke, noxious fumes, gas, soot or cinders, in unreasonable quantities. 
(18)  Any public safety alarm system the activation of which has resulted in four or more false alarms in a calendar year. 
(19)  No person shall feed wild birds other than by means of bird feeders elevated at least 48 inches above the ground levels. Birdfeeders shall be designed to be "rodent proof" or shall be properly installed with tray and baffle to prevent spillage onto the ground. No more than five birdfeeders may be placed on a lot or property. 
(20)  Properties shall be kept free of dog droppings, uneaten food, and improperly composted waste. 
(21)  No person shall leave pet or human food outside on the ground or in open containers where it is accessible to rats. No ground feeding. 
(22)  All garbage stored outside shall be in watertight plastic or metal containers with tight fitting covers sufficient to keep rats out. Plastic bags are not rat proof and shall not be used for overnight outside storage except when placed at curbside for weekly trash pickup. 
(Code 1981, § 18-2; Ord. No. 10-95, § 1, 3-6-1995; Ord. No. O-04-05, § 1, 5-2-2005; Ord. No. O-02-06, § 3, 8-21-2006; Ord. No. O-01-16, § 1, 2-1-2016) 
Sec. 78-3. - Prohibited generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to cause, permit, maintain or allow the creation or maintenance of a nuisance. 
(Code 1981, § 18-3; Ord. No. 46-95, § 1, 3-6-1995) 
Sec. 78-4. - Notice to abate. 
    Whenever a nuisance is found to exist within the city, the city manager or his designee shall give five days' written notice to the owner or occupant of the property upon which such nuisance exists or upon the person causing or maintaining the nuisance. 
(Code 1981, § 18-4) 
Sec. 78-5. - Contents of notice. 
    The notice to abate a nuisance issued under the provisions of this chapter shall contain: 
(1)  An order to abate the nuisance or to request a hearing within a stated time, which shall be reasonable under the circumstances; 
(2)  The location of the nuisance, if the nuisance is stationary; 
(3)  A description of what constitutes the nuisance; 
(4)  A statement of acts necessary to abate the nuisance; and 
(5)  A statement that if the nuisance is not abated as directed and no request for hearing is made before the city manager within the prescribed time, the city will abate such nuisance and assess the cost thereof against such person. 
(Code 1981, § 18-5) 
Sec. 78-6. - Service of notice. 
    The notice to abate a nuisance shall be served as any other legal process may be served pursuant to law. 
(Code 1981, § 18-6) 
Sec. 78-7. - Abatement by city. 
    Upon the failure of the person upon whom notice to abate a nuisance was served pursuant to the provisions of this chapter to abate the nuisance, the city manager or his designee shall proceed to abate such nuisance and shall prepare a statement of costs incurred in the abatement thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 18-7) 
Sec. 78-8. - Emergency abatement by city. 
    When, in the opinion of the city manager or his designee, there is actual and immediate danger to the public or occupants of a particular premise caused by a nuisance on such premises, the city manager or his designee is hereby authorized and empowered, without any notice or hearing, to order and require such premises to be vacated. The city manager or his designee shall immediately post the premises, warning of the dangerous condition, and shall then abate such nuisance and prepare a statement of costs incurred in the abatement thereof. 
(Code 1981, § 18-8) 
Sec. 78-9. - City's costs. 
    Any and all costs incurred by the city in the abatement of a nuisance under the provision of this chapter shall constitute a lien against the property upon which such nuisance existed, which costs shall be collected as a special assessment under chapter 102. 
(Code 1981, § 18-9) 
Chapter 82 - OFFENSES AND MISCELLANEOUS PROVISIONS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Law enforcement, ch. 62; traffic and vehicles, ch. 122. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 82-1. - Authority of peace officer to arrest assault violators without warrant. 
    A peace officer who has reasonable cause to believe that a violation of Public Act No. 328 of 1931, § 81 or 81a (MCL 750.81 or 750.81a, MSA 28.276 or 28.276(1)) or section 82-71 of this Code, has taken place or is taking place and that the person who committed or is committing the violation is a spouse, a former spouse, or a person residing or having resided in the same household as the victim, may arrest the violator without a warrant for that violation, irrespective of whether the violation was committed in the presence of the peace officer. 
(Code 1981, § 19-24) 
Sec. 82-2. - Reserved.
